title: Charleston County DSS v. Jackson
description: An incarcerated father appeals the family court order terminating his parental rights to his son.  We reverse.
text:
CCDSS v. Jackson


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Charleston County Department of Social Services,
Respondent,
v.
Priscilla Jackson, Bryan Houpe, Lamont Coles, Sr., John Doe and Stephen Doe representing the unknown biological father or fathers of Jazmyn Jackson and Lamont Coles,
Defendants,
AND Jazmyn Jackson, a child, D/O/B 6/26/90, Lamont Coles, a child, 10/15/95, of whom Lamont Coles, Sr. is
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Paul W. Garfinkel, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4090
Heard January 18, 2006 â€“ Filed March 6, 2006Â 

REVERSED


  
    
      
Cherie W Blackburn, Stephanie E. Lewis and Susan S. Quist, all of Charleston, for Appellant.
FramptonÂ  Durban, Jr., of North Charleston, for Respondent.
James C. Bradley and Michael F. Bowler, III, both of Charleston, for Guardian Ad Litem.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: The Charleston County Department of Social Services (the Department) brought this termination of parental rights (TPR) action against Lamont Coles, Sr. (Father).Â  The family court terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights to Lamont Coles, Jr. (Child), and Father appeals.Â  We reverse. Â Â 
FACTS
The origins of this case began more than ten years ago, in February of 1995, when Father met Priscilla Jackson (Mother) in Long Island, New York. At that time, Mother had a four-year-old daughter named Jazmyn.Â  In June 1995, Father was arrested for first-degree assault and robbery.Â  After pleading guilty, he was imprisoned, and has been incarcerated in a New York State prison ever since.Â  He is not eligible for parole until 2007.[1]  
Three months after Fatherâ€™s arrest in 1995, Mother gave birth to Child.Â  Shortly thereafter, Father affirmatively sought to establish paternity of Child, and in May 1996, a New York family court determined Father was Childâ€™s biological father.Â  A month after this determination, Father tried to send Child his limited inmate earnings.Â  He also attempted to arrange a life insurance policy that benefited Child. Â His attempts were in vain, however, because in November 1996, Mother, Jazmyn, and Child disappeared.[2]Â Â Â  
From that moment onward, Father engaged in an exhaustive letter-writing campaign to learn the whereabouts of Child.Â  Father wrote hundreds of letters to numerous agencies, associations, centers, organizations, and government officials.Â  Fatherâ€™s effort was so intense, the Departmentâ€™s counsel stipulated at trial that Father â€œhas done more than anybody Iâ€™ve ever seen to try to find his son and to maintain contact with the agencies that had his son.â€Â  The family court took judicial notice of the fact that Father â€œdid everything, most probably more than anyone would ever expect anyone to ever do in the history of this courtâ€ to locate his son.Â Â  
While trying to locate his son, Father expressed concern about losing his parental rights.Â  In May 1997, for example, he wrote a New York family court to ask for assistance of counsel to protect his legal rights in the event his legal connection with Child was in jeopardy because of his inability to locate Child. Â Father wrote that same court almost a year later to notify it that despite his best efforts he could not locate Child.Â  He told the family court he had contacted multiple investigators, non-profit corporations, bar associations, as well as the Ohio Departments of Social Security and Vital Statistics, which he contacted because Mother was from Ohio.Â Â Â  
Meanwhile, in South Carolina, Mother and Childâ€™s life together was unraveling.Â  In August 1997, the Department took Child into emergency protective custody based on allegations Motherâ€™s boyfriend sexually abused Jazmyn.Â  In September 1997, the family court found this abuse constituted a threat of harm to Child.Â  The family court issued a restraining order against Motherâ€™s boyfriend and approved a treatment plan requiring Mother to attend individual counseling, parent effectiveness training classes, and a substance abuse treatment program.Â  It is unclear from the record what efforts, if any, the Department made to notify or contact Father.Â  
In January 1998, the family court ordered Mother to establish and maintain stable housing and an appropriate income to support her children.Â  Again, the Departmentâ€™s efforts to notify or contact Father were either non-existent or are unknown.Â  In February 1999, Mother disappeared,[3] and during her absence, the family court established a permanent plan of TPR and adoption.Â  This action occurred in July 1999, and once again, Father was never notified, though he was still doing everything he could to locate Child.
In February 2000, Father learned from the National Missing Childrenâ€™s Locate Center in Portland, Oregon that Mother resided in South Carolina.Â  He immediately wrote Mother, but his letter was returned with an indication that she had moved.Â  Father then began writing South Carolina agencies, courts, and legal services.Â  Finally, on August 22, 2000, culminating nearly four years of searching, the South Carolina Department of Social Services wrote Father, informing him Child was in foster care in the custody of the Department.Â  The Department also advised him it could not proceed with his case until after his release from prison.Â Â Â  
Within days, on August 28, 2000, Father began to write the Department.Â  Although he did not receive a response from his initial letters, he soon discovered Sue Christopher was Childâ€™s caseworker, and he began writing to her on October 9, 2000.[4]Â  In this letter, Father apprised the Department of his extensive search to find Child and his wish to establish â€œa positive line of communicationâ€ with the Department.Â  He also notified the Department he did not want his parental rights terminated, he needed legal representation, and he had a five-year-old file of correspondence the Department could review.Â  Despite the fact that Father had been searching for information about Child for four years, the Department did not respond. 
On October 23, 2000, Father again wrote the Department.Â  Father expressed his wish to connect with Child and asked the Department about his options. Â Â The Department sent him a required form letter inviting him to a Foster Care Review Board (the Board) meeting, but did not otherwise respond.Â  On October 30, 2000, Father informed the Department he had received the Board invitation but could not attend because he was incarcerated in New York.Â  He also expressed his frustration that he had not received any information from the Department other than the invitation, and that he felt as though the Department was discouraging him from making contact with Child.Â  The Department did not respond. 
On November 1, 2000, Father again wrote the Department.Â  This time, he asked for Childâ€™s address so he could write Child.Â  He also reiterated he did not want his parental rights terminated.Â  On the same day, Father wrote the Departmentâ€™s legal counsel with the same request.Â  Neither the Department nor the Departmentâ€™s legal counsel responded.Â  On November 29, 2000, Father again wrote the Department.Â  He alerted the Department it had not responded to any of his letters, and he wanted to know his options as well as the results of the Board meeting.Â  The Department did not respond.Â  On January 4, 2001, Father again wrote the Department. Â He expressed his utter distress that the Department had not responded to any of his letters. 
Finally, on January 9, 2001, the Department responded to Father.Â  Department caseworker Christopher informed Father of the July 1999 permanence planning order directing TPR and adoption, and assured him the Department would ask the court to appoint him a Guardian ad Litem (GAL) and legal counsel to protect his rights.Â  On January 10, 2001, Department director Odessa Williams informed Father the Department had not yet commenced a TPR action against him and requested that Father furnish the Department with a list of â€œadoptive resourcesâ€ for Child.Â  This January 2001 communication is the first time the Department responded to Fatherâ€™s letters, which began in October 2000, and the first time it contacted him since it took Child into emergency protective custody in August 1997. Â Â Â Â Â 
On February 5, 2001, Father asked the Department multiple questions, including whether he could contact Child.Â  He received no reply, so Father wrote three additional letters on March 8, March 19, and April 16.Â  In these letters, he asked the Department to answer his inquiries and also requested a photograph of his son.Â  The Department did not reply to any of these letters. 
On August 6, 2001, Father wrote Department caseworker Christopher the following:

I believe [the Department] is supposed to unify families with problems, help them.Â  My son has been in foster care since [August 1997].Â  [To] this date I think that [is] over four years. . .Â  What can be done so I donâ€™t have to lose [or] give up my parental rights and forever lose my only child[?]Â  Can you, being the head of my sonâ€™s case, the only one who can provide answers, can you give me his social security number [so] at least if I die I can give [or] leave him something [?]

Christopher did not respond to this letter.Â  On August 8, 2001, the Department filed a TPR action against Father.Â  This action was taken twenty-five months after the family courtâ€™s July 1999 order establishing a permanent plan of TPR and adoption and approximately twelve months after Father learned Childâ€™s whereabouts. 
After multiple continuances, this case was tried on July 17, 2003; December 11, 2003; and June 16 and 17, 2004.Â  On August 27, 2004, the family court terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights to Child.Â  The court found Father willfully failed to visit and support Child because it took Father â€œover a year and a half to provide the identity of the persons who could assume some of his parental duties.â€Â  The court referred to the fact that Father did not provide the names of adoptive resources that Department director Williams requested in January 2001 until July 2002.Â  The court also found Child had been in foster care for fifteen out of the last twenty-two months.Â  Finally, the family court found TPR would be in the best interest of Child, noting Childâ€™s GAL recommended it.Â  Father appealed this order.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR case, the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before parental rights can be forever terminated, the alleged grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Richberg v. Dawson, 278 S.C. 356, 357, 296 S.E.2d 338, 339 (1982); S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we should not necessarily disregard the findings of the family court because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Father argues the family court erred in terminating his parental rights because (1) Father did not willfully fail to visit or support Child; (2) under the circumstances, Childâ€™s presence in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months alone is not sufficient to support TPR; (3) TPR is not in the best interest of Child; and (4) TPR violated Fatherâ€™s right to due process under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  We agree that Father did not willfully fail to visit or support child, and find that termination of Fatherâ€™s rights is not in Childâ€™s best interest.
Under the United States Constitution, natural parents are entitled to fundamentally fair procedures when the State seeks to sever the relationship they have with their child.Â  U.S. Const. amend. XIV, Â§ 1.; Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745, 753-54 (1982).Â  In Santosky, the United States Supreme Court announced: 

The fundamental liberty interest of natural parents in the care, custody, and management of their child does not evaporate simply because they have not been model parents or have lost temporary custody of their child to the State.Â  Even when blood relationships are strained, parents retain a vital interest in preventing the irretrievable destruction of their family life . . . .Â  When the State moves to destroy weakened familial bonds, it must provide the parents with fundamentally fair procedures.Â  

455 U.S. at 753.Â  The Santosky Court also noted that at the fact-finding stage, â€œthe State cannot presume that a child and his parents are adversariesâ€ because â€œthe child and his parents share a vital interest in preventing erroneous termination of their natural relationshipâ€ until the State proves parental unfitness.Â  Id. at 761.Â Â Â  
In South Carolina, the procedures for TPR are governed by statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-1560 to -1582 (Supp. 2005).Â Â  The purpose of the TPR statute is:

[T]o establish procedures for the reasonable and compassionate termination of parental rights where children are abused, neglected, or abandoned in order to protect the health and welfare of these children and make them eligible for adoption by persons who will provide a suitable home environment and the love and care necessary for a happy, healthful, and productive life.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1560 (Supp. 2005).Â  The TPR statute â€œmust be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by terminating the parent-child relationship.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2005); Joiner v. Rivas, 342 S.C. 102, 108, 536 S.E.2d 372, 375 (2000).Â  The family court may order TPR if it makes the twofold finding that plaintiff has proved by clear and convincing evidence the existence of at least one statutory ground enumerated in section 20-7-1572 and TPR would be in the best interest of the child.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Failure to Visit or Support Child
Father argues the family court erred in finding he willfully failed to visit or support Child.Â  We agree. 
The family court can terminate parental rights when TPR is in the best interest of the child and the â€œchild has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months,â€ and during that time the parent has either â€œwilfully failed to visit the childâ€ or â€œwilfully failed to support the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(3) and (4) (Supp. 2005).Â  Willful conduct is conduct that â€œevinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties . . . because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 53, 413 S.E.2d 835, 838 (1992).Â  Whether a parent has willfully failed to visit or support his or her child is a â€œquestion of intent to be determined from the facts and circumstances of each individual case.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 610, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003); Stinecipher v. Ballington, 366 S.C. 92, 98, 620 S.E.2d 93, 96 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The family court has wide discretion to make this determination, but the element of willfulness must be established by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Broome, 307 S.C. at 52, 413 S.E.2d at 838.Â  â€œThe court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, including . . . the ability of the parent to provide support.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572.Â  
Incarceration alone is insufficient to justify TPR.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 332, 337, 543 S.E.2d 580, 583 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In Wilson, the father was incarcerated after the birth of his three children.Â  Two years after his incarceration, the Department took his children into emergency protective custody.Â  A year later, the Department brought a TPR action against the father for willful failure to visit his children.Â  The family court ordered TPR, even though the father requested an opportunity to visit his children at each review hearing.Â  We reversed the family court, holding that â€œ[t]erminating the parental rights of an incarcerated parent requires consideration of all of the surrounding facts and circumstances in the determination of wilfulness.â€Â  Id. at 340, 543 S.E.2d at 584.Â  We noted the record was replete with evidence of not only the fatherâ€™s repeated requests to the Department to visit his children, but also the Departmentâ€™s active role in thwarting the fatherâ€™s attempts to visit his children.Â  Id. at 338, 543 S.E.2d at 583.[5]Â Â Â Â Â  
In this case, the record demonstrates the Departmentâ€™s blatant indifference to Fatherâ€™s plight.Â  The Department took Child into emergency custody in August 1997.Â  The Department should have contacted Father at this time.Â  Instead, it appears the Department conducted the case as if Father did not exist.Â  In September 1997, the Department recommended, and the family court adopted, a treatment plan requiring Mother to attend individual counseling, parent effectiveness training classes, and a substance abuse treatment program.Â  The Department did not recommend a treatment plan for Father even though, by Department caseworker Christopherâ€™s own admission, one could have been recommended.Â  When Mother eventually failed to complete her treatment plan, the family court established a permanent plan of TPR and adoption.Â  Again, the Department did not contact Father, even though he risked losing his parental rights to Child.Â  
For reasons even the Department was unable to explain, the Department took more than two years to file a complaint seeking to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights to Child.Â  During this interim, Father discovered, after four years of searching, that the Department had custody of Child.Â  On October 9, 2000, he wrote Christopher a letter explaining his circumstances and hoping to establish a â€œpositive line of communicationâ€ with the Department.Â  Thus, it took the Department over three years to make contact with Father, and even then, the communication occurred only because Father contacted the Department as a result of his extraordinary efforts to locate Child.Â  It then took Christopher three months to respond.Â  Father continued to write.Â  He indicated he wanted to communicate with Child; he asked for Childâ€™s picture, address, and social security number.Â  He also asked to visit, or at the very least, to write Child.Â  Despite Fatherâ€™s multiple requests, Christopher did not respond until seven months later, on March 18, 2002.[6]Â  By the time Father received this letter, the Department had already brought a TPR action against him.Â Â Â  
Christopher did not assist in connecting Child with his natural father.Â  She did not provide Father with any information that would help him communicate with Child, nor did she send him a picture of Child as Father requested.Â  At trial, Christopher testified she could not provide Father with the information he requested because a Department-hired therapist, Karen Tarpey, recommended Child not communicate with Father because it would not be in Childâ€™s best interest.[7]Â  Â However, Christopher never told Father this was the reason she continued to deny him access to any information regarding contact with Child. Â Instead, she simply did not respond to him.Â Â Â  
Even assuming Christopher had told Father about Tarpeyâ€™s recommendation, there is not much Father could have done about it.Â  The fact remained Father could not communicate with Child because the Department would not allow him to contact Child.Â  Therefore, even if Father had been provided an address to write Child letters, or send him birthday cards, Child would not have received them.Â  The Department would not have allowed Fatherâ€™s correspondence to reach Child because Tarpey opined Childâ€™s exposure to Father would be detrimental.Â  
The Department can certainly rely on the opinion of a therapeutic expert in determining what is in the best interest of a child in its custody; however, if the expert recommends the child not have parental contact without even contacting the parent herself, it is disingenuous for the Department to initiate a TPR action against the parent for not contacting child.Â  Consequently, even assuming therapist Tarpeyâ€™s recommendation is correct, the mere fact that it may be detrimental to Child for Father to contact Child does not mean Fatherâ€™s parental rights should be automatically terminated. 
Based on the record, we find the Department did not demonstrate Father was so indifferent to the right of Child to receive his support and consortium that Father willfully failed to visit and support him.Â  To the contrary, the record reflects Father actively sought to visit and support Child, and, if anything, was prevented from exercising his parental duties because the Department was indifferent to his parental rights.Â  Father could not communicate with Child, let alone visit him, because the Department forbade him from doing so based on Tarpeyâ€™s recommendation.Â  Father was not able to send money to Child despite his attempts to do so because the Department never provided him with an address of where to send a check. 
The family court emphasized the fact that after Father received a response from the Department in January 2001, he did not furnish a list of adoptive resources until July 2002. Â To the extent such a list is relevant, let alone dispositive, in determining whether Fatherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated, we find Fatherâ€™s delay in providing the Department with a list of adoptive resources does not show a settled purpose to forego his parental duties.Â  Because Father grew up in foster care, he recommended his foster mother and foster sister as adoptive resources.Â  Although his foster mother testified she was no longer interested in adopting Child, his foster sister said she was still interested.Â  This recommendation, while not perfect, was nevertheless viable.Â  Moreover, if the Department had made an effort to contact Father when it initially took Child into emergency protective custody in August 1997, Father would have had more options than he does now.Â  In 1997, for example, Fatherâ€™s foster mother, biological father, and biological brother were all possibilities.Â  As Father testified at trial, with the passing years, â€œa lot of things started happening that no one [could] control.â€ Â Â Finally, the mere fact that Father was unable to find a suitable adoptive resource, does not necessarily mean Father willfully failed to visit or support Child.Â Â Â Â Â  
After considering all relevant facts and circumstances, we hold the Department did not establish by clear and convincing evidence that Father willfully failed to visit or support Child.Â  Accordingly, the family court erred in terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights based on his willful failure to visit and support Child. 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Child in Foster Care
Father argues that, under the circumstances, Childâ€™s presence in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months alone is not sufficient to support TPR.Â  We disagree.Â  
The family court can terminate parental rights when it is in the best interest of the child and the â€œchild has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1572(8).Â  â€œA finding pursuant to section 20-7-1572(8) alone is sufficient to support a termination of parental rights.â€Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359 S.C. 601, 608, 598 S.E.2d 303, 307 (Ct. App. 2004); see also Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 581, 578 S.E.2d 733, 736 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  
Father points out that he had only been made aware of Childâ€™s presence in foster care twelve months prior to the filing of the TPR action.Â  However, the purpose of the statutory ground allowing for termination if a child has been in foster care for fifteen of the last twenty-two months is to ensure children do not languish in foster care when termination of parental rights would be in their best interests.Â  Doe, 353 S.C. at 581, 578 S.E.2d at 736 (â€œTPR statutes must be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by terminating the parent-child relationship.â€).Â  Thus, it is the childâ€™s perspective, and not the parentâ€™s, that we are concerned with when determining whether this statutory ground has been met.Â  Here, the letter of the law was met once Child resided in foster care for fifteen of the last twenty-two months regardless of Fatherâ€™s knowledge of Childâ€™s whereabouts.[8]
III.Â Â Â  Best Interest of Child 
Father argues TPR is not in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  We agree. 
In TPR cases, the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Vanderhorst, 287 S.C. 554, 561, 340 S.E.2d 149, 153 (1986).Â  â€œThe interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2005).
Child currently resides in a therapeutic foster home with his sister Jazmyn.Â  Both children have special needs.Â  Child has some learning disabilities.Â  Because the two children support each other, all parties, including Father, agree they should remain together.[9]Â  However, there is no assurance the children will remain together, or even at the same foster home.Â  Childâ€™s current foster parents wish to remain as foster parents and, as of the TPR hearing, have not expressed an interest in adopting him.Â  Thus, terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights will not ensure future stability for Child.Â  Moreover, keeping Fatherâ€™s parental rights intact will not disrupt Childâ€™s current living situation.Â Â  Father does not gain custody of Child simply because the Department failed to terminate his parental rights at this time.Â  Rather, by not terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights, Father merely maintains his right to connect with Child as well as his obligation to support Child, emotionally, financially, or otherwise.Â  The Department should, in the best interest of Child, facilitate this connection and accompanying obligation.Â Â  
The family court noted that Childâ€™s guardian ad litem, William Jordan, recommended TPR would be in the best interest of Child.Â Â  However, Jordan testified that he did not know if Child would be harmed by contact with Father.Â Â  Jordan could not opine on the matter because he never spoke with Father and never talked to Child about Father.Â  Jordan also admitted he never responded to any of Fatherâ€™s correspondence, but said he let his counsel know about it.Â  Accordingly, Childâ€™s GAL recommended terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights without talking to Child about Fatherâ€™s existence and without talking to Father at all.[10]Â  Under these circumstances, we do not understand how Childâ€™s GAL can recommend TPR without any investigation into the situation between Child and his natural father.[11]Â  
Fatherâ€™s tireless efforts to connect with Child demonstrate a sincere concern for Childâ€™s well-being. Again, when Father learned of Childâ€™s birth, he immediately established paternity.Â  When Child disappeared, Father wrote hundreds of letters to try to locate Child.Â  After Father found Child, he wrote hundreds more to try to contact him, or even just to have a photograph of him.Â  In addition to expressing a desire to emotionally support Child, Fatherâ€™s letters expressed a desire to financially support Child with what little resources Father had.Â  As the Department stipulated, Father â€œhas done more than anybody [the Departmentâ€™s attorney had] ever seen to try to find his son and to maintain contact with the agencies that had his son.â€Â  Unless long-term incarceration alone is enough to terminate parental rights, which is not the case in South Carolina,[12] we cannot discern any evidence from the record before us indicating termination would be in Childâ€™s best interests.Â  Childâ€™s foster parents are not willing to adopt him, Fatherâ€™s efforts to maintain a relationship with Child have been extraordinary, and the social worker who advised against communication between Father and Child had neither spoken with Father nor spoken to Child about Father. 
Fatherâ€™s connection with Child may be faint, but it is nevertheless existent.Â  It is also a fundamental liberty interest protected by the United States Constitution.Â  Santosky, 455 U.S. at 753.Â  Such an interest cannot be severed where, as here, the Department failed to present any reason why termination of parental rights would be in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  Accordingly, the family court erred in terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights.Â Â  
IV.Â Â Â  Due Process Violation 
Father argues TPR violates his right to due process under the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.Â  However, this issue was not raised to or ruled upon by the family court, and therefore it is not preserved for review.Â  Staubes v. City of Folly Beach, 339 S.C. 406, 412, 529 S.E.2d 543, 546 (2000) (â€œIt is well-settled that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Jones v. Daley, 363 S.C. 310, 315, 609 S.E.2d 597, 599 (Ct. App. 2005). 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing reasoning, the family court order terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights is 
REVERSED.
ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Father was also eligible for parole in July 2005, but at the time of oral argument in January of 2006, Father was still incarcerated.Â  
[2]Â  Apparently, the trio moved to South Carolina without telling Father.Â Â Â  
[3]Â  The Department did not locate her until September 2001.Â Â  
[4]Â  This is the first time the Department acknowledges contact with Father.Â  
[5] Â Compare Wilson to South Carolina Department of Social Services v. Ledford, 357 S.C. 371, 376, 593 S.E.2d 175, 177 (Ct. App. 2004), where we upheld the essential holding of Wilson that incarceration alone is insufficient to justify TPR.Â  In Ledford, the father was incarcerated in Georgia.Â  He only attempted to contact his child twice, and was unsuccessful on both occasions.Â  After a SCDSS caseworker found him via an internet search of the Georgia Department of Corrections, the father made no effort to contact the caseworker or any other SCDSS employee.Â  After SCDSS brought a TPR action against the father, he still made no effort to contact SCDSS.Â  The family court terminated his parental rights and we affirmed.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
[6]Â  This is only the second response Father received from Christopher, his sonâ€™s caseworker at the Department, since his initial letter of October 9, 2000.Â  
[7]Â  Karen Tarpey is a licensed independent social worker, with a masterâ€™s degree in social work, who accepts referrals from the Department.Â  There is no indication in the record that Ms. Tarpey ever contacted Father prior to making this recommendation.
[8] We note that although the letter of the law was met in this particular case, especially considering Fatherâ€™s incarceration will continue to necessitate foster care for Child, there may be some instances where this statutory ground would not support termination of parental rights despite the passage of a fifteen month stay in foster care.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cochran, 356 S.C. 413, 420, 589 S.E.2d 753, 756 (2003) (Pleicones, J., concurring) (â€œI am not willing to sever the parent-child relationship solely on the basis that the child has spent fifteen of twenty-two months in foster care where the appellant presented substantial evidence that much of the delay in the processing of this case is attributable to the acts of others.â€).
[9]Â  The two children were not placed together in the same foster home until three years after the Department obtained custody of them.Â Â Â  
[10]Â  Jordan submitted his report on July 16, 2003.Â  Accordingly, pursuant to section 20-7-1549 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), which became effective on January 15, 2003, Jordan had a duty and obligation to conduct an â€œindependent, balanced, and impartial investigation to determine the facts relevant to the situation of the child and the family,â€ including a mandatory interview of Childâ€™s parents.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1549(A)(2)(iv).Â Â Â Â  
[11]Â  We also do not understand how Childâ€™s therapist, Karen Tarpey, can recommend Father not contact Child without ever talking to Child about Father, and without talking to Father at all.Â Â Â  
[12] If the South Carolina General Assembly intended long-term incarceration alone to justify termination of parental rights, it would have made such a provision in the statute.Â  In many states, incarceration is a ground for termination, though even then, the best interests of the child are considered.Â  See, e.g., Ala. title: West v. Alliance Capital and Frontier Insurance Company
description: This workers' compensation case asks whether injuries incurred while employees were working on a personal vehicle at a job site during work time are compensable.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Charles West, Respondent,
v.
Alliance Capital and Frontier Insurance Company,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â S. Jackson Kimball, III, Master - In - Equity

Opinion No. 4091
Heard January 11, 2006 â€“ Filed March 6, 2006Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Donald L. Van Riper, Suzanne C. Boulware, of Columbia, for Appellants. 
William P. Walker, Jr., of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, an explosion at work injured Charles West while he performed repairs on his own truck during working hours and using his employerâ€™s equipment.Â  The Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission adopted the order of the single commissioner and found that the injury arose out of and in the course of Westâ€™s employment.Â  The circuit court affirmed.Â  We now affirm. 
FACTS
Alliance Capital employed West and leased his services to Meylan Enterprises.Â  Frontier Insurance Company provided workersâ€™ compensation insurance to Alliance Capital and Meylan.Â  Meylan conducts business in many states and is primarily involved in heavy industrial cleaning at nuclear power plants and manufacturing facilities.Â  Westâ€™s supervisor, Tex Williams, described West as a â€œforeman . . . [who] overs[aw] the shop activities and all the mechanic work that goes on.â€Â  The injury here occurred at Meylanâ€™s Rock Hill, South Carolina facility.Â  
Meylan required its employees to come to work, clock in and, in the absence of an off-site job assignment, remain on the premises for their eight-hour shift.Â  West and his fellow employees had to be present at the shop (or on a job assignment) to get paid.Â  Because the actual work was sporadic, employees at the Rock Hill facility were to await calls at the shop and do various tasks in preparation for upcoming job assignments.Â  While awaiting job assignments, employees could use their free time as they chose, provided they remained on site.Â  Meylan employees generally spent about half of their time at the shop preparing for a project or on standby and the other half of their time working at job sites.Â  
The single commissioner found that a custom and practice existed at Meylanâ€™s shops of allowing employees, during working hours, to work on their own vehicles in the shop, using shop equipment.Â  Meylanâ€™s supervisors never prohibited or otherwise discouraged this practice.Â  The record contains many examples of Meylanâ€™s acquiescence and approval of this practice, including an instance where Williams, the supervisor, brought his sonâ€™s car into the shop for body work.Â  
Meylan lacked a sufficient number of vehicles at the Rock Hill facility to transport people and equipment to the job sites.Â  Williams, for example, often used his personal vehicle to take people and supplies to and from jobs.Â  West informed Williams he had a truck that could be used to assist in transporting people and equipment.Â  The vehicle was at that time inoperable, and Williams authorized West to travel to West Virginia to transport the truck to Rock Hill for repairs so Meylan could use it for transportation.Â  
Several weeks before the accident, West and another Meylan employee drove to West Virginia in a Meylan truck and trailer.Â  Meylan paid West for the trip, including his expenses.Â  Meylan expected to benefit from use of the truck for its operations.Â  When delivered to Rock Hill, the truck was stored in the enclosed shop area of the Meylan facility, where it remained for â€œprobably two or three weeksâ€ prior to the accident.Â  
On the date of the accident, West completed his work and waited for other Meylan employees to return from a job assignment.Â  During this downtime, West decided to work on the truck.Â  West and another employee removed the gas tank from the truck to clean it.Â  After emptying the gas out of the tank, West began sandblasting the inside of the tank using Meylan equipment.Â  The tank exploded, injuring both employees.[1]Â  West received second-degree and third-degree burns over fifty-four percent of his body.Â  
The single commissioner found that the injury to West arose out of and in the course of his employment, noting that the truck repair was for Meylanâ€™s benefit, on company time, in Meylanâ€™s shop, with Meylanâ€™s equipment, and with Meylanâ€™s permission.Â  The single commissioner thus found the injury compensable and awarded benefits.Â  On review, the Commission affirmed, adopting the order of the single commissioner.Â  Alliance Capital appealed to the circuit court, challenging the finding that the injury arose out of and in the course of Westâ€™s employment.Â  The circuit court affirmed.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act (APA) establishes the standard for judicial review of decisions of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  See Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380 (2005).Â  A reviewing court may reverse or modify a decision of an administrative agency if â€œthe findings, inferences, conclusions or decisions of that agency are clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€ Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 288, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610 (Ct. App. 2004) (quoting Bursey v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 60 S.C. 135, 141, 600 S.E.2d 80, 84 (Ct. App. 2004)).Â  Under the scope of review established in the APA, this Court may not substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact, but may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Frame v. Resort Servs., Inc., 357 S.C. 520, 527, 593 S.E.2d 491, 495 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act requires that an injury by accident must be one â€œarising out ofâ€ and â€œin the course of employmentâ€ to be compensable.Â  Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 638 (Ct. App. 1999); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2005).Â  The injury must both â€œarise out ofâ€ and occur â€œin the course of employmentâ€ to allow recovery.Â  Broughton, 336 S.C. at 496, 520 S.E.2d at 634.Â  As presented here, the question is largely one of fact for the Commission.Â  Id.Â  The claimant has the burden of proving facts sufficient to allow recovery under the Act.Â  Id.Â Â Â  
Â I. Did the injury arise out of the employment?
Alliance Capital first argues that the injury did not arise out of Westâ€™s employment because no causal connection existed between the working conditions and his injury.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
â€œThe phrase â€˜arising out ofâ€™ in the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act refers to the injuryâ€™s origin and cause.â€Â  Broughton, 336 S.C. at 497, 520 S.E.2d at 638.Â  For an injury to â€œarise out ofâ€ employment it must proximately cause the injury.Â  Id.Â  There must be a causal connection between the conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the resulting injury.Â  Osteen v. Greenville County Sch. Dist., 333 S.C. 43, 50, 508 S.E.2d 21, 25 (1998).Â  
The requisite causal connection has been described as follows:Â  

[I]f the injury can be seen to have followed as a natural incident of the work and to have been contemplated by a reasonable person familiar with the whole situation as a result of the exposure occasioned by the nature of the employment, then it arises â€˜out ofâ€™ the employment.Â  But it excludes an injury which cannot fairly be traced to the employment as a contributing proximate cause and which comes from a hazard to which the workmen would have been equally exposed apart from the employment.Â  The causative danger must be peculiar to the work and not common to the neighborhood.Â  It must be incidental to the character of the business and not independent of the relation of master and servant.Â  It need not have been foreseen or expected, but after the event it must appear to have had its origin in a risk connected with the employment, and to have flowed from that source as a rational consequence.Â  

Douglas v. Spartan Mills, Startex Div., 245 S.C. 265, 269, 140 S.E.2d 173, 175 (1965).Â  
Alliance Capital argues the employment did not proximately cause the injury because Westâ€™s injury arose from merely permissive activities, not required duties.Â  Alliance Capital relies on Osteen, 333 S.C. 43, 508 S.E.2d 21.Â  In Osteen, an attendance clerk working at an elementary school injured her back filling her ice chest with ice from the school cafeteria and placing it into her car.Â  Id. at 45-46, 508 S.E.2d at 22.Â  The court held the activity to be permissive, and thus no causal connection existed between Osteenâ€™s employment and her injury.Â  Id. at 50, 508 S.E.2d at 25.Â  
In another case, the court found no causal connection when an employee was injured after leaving work to check on an ill employee.Â  Broughton, 336 S.C. at 497-98, 520 S.E.2d at 638.Â  The court noted that the claimantâ€™s job requirements did not include leaving work to check on sick co-workers.Â  Id.Â  
In both Osteen and Broughton, however, the claimants sustained injuries during activities entirely unrelated to their work duties.Â  Here, the record supports the findingâ€”to the substantial evidence standardâ€”that the truck would be utilized in Meylanâ€™s operations following repairs.Â  A shortage of trucks existed, and West had volunteered the use of his truck once it was restored to operable condition.Â  According to West, whose testimony the Commission deemed credible,[2] supervisor Williams â€œknew that I was wanting to use [the truck] for work.â€ Williams authorized West to drive to West Virginia on company time and at company expense to bring the truck to the shop in Rock Hill, and permitted the truck to be kept at the shop.Â  Williams knew the repairs were necessary to make the truck operational.Â  
Westâ€™s injury arose out of the employment because the truck was being repaired for Meylanâ€™s benefit, using company resources, with Meylanâ€™s consent.Â  We conclude the record establishes the requisite causal connection between the working conditions and the injury.[3]Â  
II. Did the injury occur in the course of employment?
Alliance Capital next argues that the injury did not occur in the course of Westâ€™s employment.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œThe phrase â€˜in the course of the employmentâ€™ refers to the time, place, and circumstances under which the accident occurred.â€Â  Broughton, 336 S.C. at 498, 520 S.E.2d at 639.Â  â€œAn injury occurs â€˜in the course ofâ€™ employment within the meaning of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act when it occurs within the period of employment at a place where the employee reasonably may be in the performance of his duties and while fulfilling those duties or engaged in something incidental thereto.â€Â  Id.Â  
A key factor in determining entitlement to compensation under this prong is whether an employeeâ€™s activity benefited the employer.Â  Hicks v. Piedmont Cold Storage, Inc., 335 S.C. 46, 49, 515 S.E.2d 532, 533 (1999).Â  In Hicks, the court denied compensation to an employee who was repairing a personal vehicle at the worksite.Â  The circumstances of Westâ€™s injury present an entirely different situation, for the injury in Hicks occurred on a Saturday, during non-working hours, during work for which the employee received no compensation, and the employer derived no benefit from the vehicle repair.Â  Id.Â  Here, the employer paid West for repairing the vehicle at the worksite, and the activity occurred during working hours, using tools furnished by his employer and for the purpose of remedying the employerâ€™s vehicle shortage at the Rock Hill site.Â  The record sustains the finding that Westâ€™s injury occurred in the course of his employment with Meylan.
CONCLUSION
We hold that the truck repair was an activity arising out of and in the course of Westâ€™s employment with Meylan, and the resulting injury was compensable.Â Â  
 AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL, J., concur.Â  

[1]  The other employee settled his workersâ€™ compensation claim.
[2]  We decline, pursuant to our standard of review, Alliance Capitalâ€™s invitation to assign credibility to Williamsâ€™ contrary testimony.Â  Fact-finding is a matter exclusively within the province of the Commission.Â  Kennedy v. Williamsburg County, 242 S.C. 477, 480, 131 S.E.2d 512, 513 (1963).Â  
[3]  Because we find substantial evidence supports the finding that Westâ€™s truck was intended for use in Meylanâ€™s operations, we need not address the alternative groundsâ€”the personal comfort doctrineâ€”relied on by the Commission.Â  Osteen, 333 S.C. at 47-48, 508 S.E.2d at 23 (observing that under workersâ€™ compensation law, â€œthe personal comfort doctrine has consistently been limited to imperative acts such as eating, drinking, smoking, seeking relief from discomfort, preparing to begin or quit work, and resting or sleepingâ€); see also Dukes v. Rural Metro Corp., 356 S.C. 107, 110, 587 S.E.2d 687, 689 (2003) (â€œThe purpose of the personal comfort doctrine is to allow employees to attend to their biological personal requirements.â€).

title: Cedar Cove Homeowners Association, Inc. v. DiPietro
description: This action involves the interpretation and application of a subdivision's restictive covenants in the context of the homeowners' association's attempt to compel the removal, by way of a mandatory injunction, of a landowner's encroachment onto the common areas of the subdivision.
text:
<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Cedar Cove Homeowners Association, Inc., Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Rudy DiPietro and Margaret L. DiPietro, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â JosephÂ  M. Strickland, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. Â 4092
Heard February 6, 2006 â€“ Filed March 13, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      Rolf Mouin Baghdady, for Appellants.
      Spencer Andrew Syrett, of Columbia, for Respondent.
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This appeal concerns the construction of restrictive covenants.Â  Rudy and Margaret DiPietro are residents of the Cedar Cove subdivision in Richland County, South Carolina.Â  The Cedar Cove Homeownersâ€™ Association (the Association) sought and obtained an injunction requiring the DiPietros to remove a brick patio that encroached approximately three feet onto the common area of the subdivision.Â  The DiPietros appeal, and we reverse. Â We find the Declaration of Covenants governing the Cedar Cove Subdivision and a balancing of the equities preclude the issuance of the injunction.Â  
FACTS / PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Margaret and Rudy DiPietro have been residents in Cedar Cove since 1998.Â  The subdivision is managed by the Association, which operates pursuant to by-laws.Â  The property of Cedar Cove is subject to restrictive covenants, known as the â€œDeclaration of Covenants, Conditions, and Restrictions for Cedar Cove Subdivision.â€
A previous owner of the DiPietro lot built a wooden deck behind the house, part of which encroached onto the common area.Â  The Association has never challenged the wooden deck and its encroachment onto the common area.Â  In 2001, the DiPietros desired to construct a patio underneath the deck, primarily because the area under the deck was â€œunsightly, and there was some soil erosion . . . .â€Â  Like the wooden deck, the patio would slightly encroach onto the common area.Â  Rudy DiPietro pursued the desired patio by following the then longstanding informal approach to such matters in Cedar Cove, for strict compliance with the procedural requirements in the restrictive covenants was largely ignored.[1]Â  Rudy prepared a sketch of the proposed patio and presented it to Clark Cowsert, a member of the Architectural Review Committee at the time.
Cowsert met with Rudy, reviewed the sketch, and even assisted with â€œpull[ing] a string acrossâ€ the ground to determine the precise location and parameters of the patio.Â  Cowsert recommended approval of the patio request to Mike Reed, then president of the Associationâ€™s Board of Directors.Â  According to Cowsert, â€œI gave it to Mr. Reed who was president of the Board[] and everything went according to what my recommendation was.â€Â  Reed also inspected the site, and the record establishes that Reed approved of the patio.Â  Even the Association concedes that â€œthere was some level of approval by Mike Reed.â€Â  Rudy then proceeded with construction of the patio.
In 2002, new officers were elected, and the days of lax governance were over.Â  As the Associationâ€™s new president, Doug Harder, said, â€œWe try to run the Association like a business.â€Â  The DiPietros were perhaps the first to experience the â€œbusinessâ€ approach.Â  On April 8, 2002, Harder and Charles Zinco, chairman of the Architectural Review Committee, delivered a letter to Rudy, directing Rudy to â€œstop construction.â€Â  As of April 8, 2002, the patio was substantially completed.[2]Â  Rudy was angered by the Associationâ€™s tactics and so informed Harder and Zinco with a â€œfew choice words.â€Â  When Zinco was asked whether it was his â€œimpression that [Rudy] intended to complete the project without further consultation with you all,â€ he responded, â€œOh, yes.Â  Yes, sir.â€Â  Harder expressed similar sentiments, stating that Rudy â€œdid make it known to usâ€ that he was not going to stop construction.Â  As expected, Rudy proceeded to complete the patio.
The Association delayed in taking action, perhaps because the new officers knew Reed, the former board president, gave â€œsome level of approvalâ€ to the DiPietrosâ€™ patio project.Â  According to Harder, there were a number of reasons for the boardâ€™s prolonged inaction:

  First of all, we are a volunteer board, and we have lives to live and families to raise, and all three of us, as I recall were traveling a great deal during that spring and summertime.Â  I suppose in trying to â€“ we were trying to come up with some way that maybe we could convince Rudy to voluntarily stop, but I guess the summer got away from us enjoying our time on the lake.Â  So it was no conscious decisioin [sic] about, you know, delaying for any reason.Â  We had no attorney for the association at the time.Â  We had to begin, you know, a search for one.Â  That took some time. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

The Association filed its Complaint on January 15, 2003.Â  By then, the patio was completed.Â  The Complaint alleges a trespass on the basis that the patio encroaches on the common areas, in violation of Articles V and VI of the restrictive covenants.Â  The claim for damages was withdrawn at trial, and the Association sought a mandatory injunction â€œdirecting [the DiPietros] to remove that portion of the brick patio that encroaches and trespasses onto the common areas owned by [the Association].â€Â  The master granted the injunction on the basis that the DiPietros failed to â€œsecure the approvalâ€ of the Association in accordance with the restrictive covenants.Â  The DiPietros appealed following an unsuccessful motion to reconsider.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
While a trespass action is one at law, the Association withdrew its claim for damages and sought only an injunction.Â  The character of an action as legal or equitable depends on the relief sought.Â  Compare Oâ€™Shea v. Lesser, 308 S.C. 10, 14, 416 S.E.2d 629, 631 (1992) (holding an action for breach of restrictive covenants was at law, because relief sought was general damages for loss of view and invasion of privacy) and Kneale v. Bonds, 317 S.C. 262, 265, 452 S.E.2d 840, 841 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œAn action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is in equity.â€); see also S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 622, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302 (2001) (holding an action to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction is an equitable action).Â  Because the Associationâ€™s action is one to enforce restrictive covenants by injunction, it is in equity, and we may find facts in accordance with our own view of the evidence.Â  Brenco v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 363 S.C. 136, 142, 609 S.E.2d 531, 534 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  We acknowledge the superior position of the trial judge to assess witness credibility.Â  We would not, even under de novo review, lightly disregard a trial judgeâ€™s credibility determinations.Â  The resolution of this appeal, however, turns not on a credibility assessment, but on the application of largely undisputed facts to unambiguous restrictive covenants.Â  Moser v. Gosnell, 334 S.C. 425, 430, 513 S.E.2d 123, 125 (Ct. App. 1999) (holding that when a covenant or contract is clear and unambiguous, matters of construction are questions of law for the court).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS 
The DiPietros contend the master erred in granting the injunction.Â  We agree.
We first dispense with the suggestion that because the common area of the Cedar Cove subdivision is involved, the law of trespass governs and trumps the clear language of the restrictive covenants.Â  Where, as here, issues involving the common area of a subdivisionâ€”as raised by the pleadingsâ€”are resolved by reference to the applicable restrictive covenants, those covenants control.Â  The Associationâ€™s charge of trespass against the DiPietros emanates solely from the restrictive covenants.Â  Indeed, the Associationâ€™s Complaint cites no source to support its claim for relief other than the restrictive covenants.Â  This case was pled and tried on the theory that the DiPietros violated the restrictive covenantsâ€”specifically Articles V and VIâ€”by failing to properly secure approval for the patio.Â  
Article V of the restrictive covenants controls the resolution of this appeal:
Article V
Architectural Control

  
    No building, fence, wall or other structure shall be commenced, erected or maintained upon the Properties, nor shall any exterior addition to or change or alteration therein be made until the plans and specifications showing the nature, kind, shape, color, height, materials and location of the same shall have been submitted to and approved in writing as to harmony of external design and location in relation to surrounding structures and topography by the Declarant, or by a designated representative.Â  Such approval shall be determined by consideration of the workmanship, materials, harmony or exterior design with existing structures, and location with respect to topography and grade.Â  PROVIDED HOWEVER, that if approval or disapproval is not submitted, or no suit to enjoin construction is commenced prior to substantial completion thereof, it shall be presumed that the party has fully complied with this restriction. 
  

(Emphasis added). 
We find that Mike Reed gave â€œapprovalâ€ to the patio project, according to the longstanding informal approach to restrictive covenant compliance that existed at the time.Â  In any event, we believe the DiPietros must prevail irrespective of formal approval of the project.Â  It is undisputed that there has never been a formal â€œdisapprovalâ€ as contemplated by the restrictive covenants.Â  Harder was asked whether his â€œletter of April 8th [was] intended to be a disapproval of [the] project?â€ Harder answered, â€œNo.â€Â  The goal sought by the Association in the April 8 letter was â€œto stop, talk, and try to come to a resolution.â€Â  Association representatives, however, understood well that Rudy intended to finish the project, and yet the Association took no action until months later after the patio was completed.Â  The Association, which claims a desire for strict compliance with the covenants, may not escape from its own lack of compliance with the restrictive covenants.
We are then left with the provision that compliance with the restrictive covenants â€œshall be presumed . . . [if] no suit to enjoin construction is commenced prior to substantial completion thereof.â€Â  It is unchallenged, and the master so found, that after the April 8 letter and prior to this action, the DiPietros â€œproceeded to complete the project.â€Â  We adhere to the unambiguous terms of the restrictive covenants.[3]Â  Accordingly, we hold the DiPietros are entitled to the presumption of compliance and that the granting of the injunction was therefore in error.Â  See Sea Pines Plantation Co. v. Wells, 294 S.C. 266, 270, 363 S.E.2d 891, 894 (1987) (noting that restrictive covenants are voluntary contracts between the parties, and courts should enforce such contracts unless they are indefinite or violate public policy). 
Â Our reversal of the injunction based on a straightforward application of Article V of the restrictive covenants is further supported by our firm view that a balancing of the equities compels the denial of injunctive relief.Â  See Wells, 294 S.C. at 274, 363 S.E.2d at 896 (â€œA court does not automatically issue a mandatory injunction once it finds a restrictive covenant has been violated [as] [t]he court must balance the equities between the parties . . . .â€); Hunnicutt v. Rickenbacker, 268 S.C. 511, 515, 234 S.E.2d 887, 889 (1977) (â€œ[I]t is not every case of a structure erected in violation of a restriction which will call for [a mandatory injunction].â€); Rabon v. Mali, 289 S.C. 37, 40, 344 S.E.2d 608, 610 (1986) (holding equity will refuse her aid when a party, knowing his rights, suffers his adversary to incur expenses, enter into obligations, or otherwise change his position before asserting a claim for enforcement, â€œespecially if an injunction is [requested]â€); Janasik v. Fairway Oaks Villas Horizontal Prop. Regime, 307 S.C. 339, 344-45, 415 S.E.2d 384, 387-88 (1992) (holding a horizontal property regime waived its right to enforce a restrictive covenant by failing to bring a claim for enforcement against a known violation until after a substantial amount was spent on improvements).Â  Having reversed the mandatory injunction, we do not reach the DiPietrosâ€™ remaining assignments of error.Â  Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (noting that an appellate court need not address the remaining issues when disposition of a prior issue is dispositive).
CONCLUSION 
We find that under the terms of the restrictive covenants the Association is not entitled to a mandatory injunction requiring the removal of the patio.Â  The order of the master granting the injunction isÂ  
REVERSED. 
HEARN, C.J., concurs, and ANDERSON, J., dissents in a separate opinion. 
ANDERSON, J. (dissenting in a separate opinion):Â  I disagree with the majorityâ€™s reasoning and analysis.Â  I VOTE to AFFIRM.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Margaret and Rudy DiPietro are the owners of Lot 5 in the Cedar Cove Subdivision and have resided there since 1998.Â  The subdivision is governed by the Cedar Cove Homeownersâ€™ Association (the Association), a non-profit corporation organized and existing under the laws of South Carolina.Â  Management of the Association is governed by the By-Laws.Â  Both the common areas of the subdivision and Lot 5 are subject to the Declaration of Covenants, Conditions, and Restrictions for Cedar Cove Subdivision (the restrictive covenants).Â Â  
Pursuant to the restrictive covenants, to gain approval for exterior work on oneâ€™s home, an owner must submit plans to the architectural review committee.Â  The plans are then presented to the Board for final approval.Â  In 2001, the DiPietros made an oral application to the Chairman of the Architectural Control Committee, Clark Cowsert, for approval to construct a brick patio behind their residence.Â  Cowsert visually inspected the proposed project and assisted the DiPietros in laying out the plan.Â  There is a question as to whether the plan contemplated an encroachment onto the common areas of the Association.Â  No written approval of the project was ever issued.Â  Cowsert only had authority to recommend the project to the Board of Directors.Â  He could not approve any project himself.Â Â  
Prior to completion of the DiPietrosâ€™ addition, the Board membership changed.Â  The new Board considered the project and determined that it had no authority to consent to an encroachment onto the common areas.Â  The Board instructed the DiPietros to cease work and directed them to remove the portion of the patio that encroached on the common areas.Â  Mr. DiPietro informed the Board he had permission from the previous Board and he did not intend to stop construction.Â  The Board concluded that though there may have been some previous level of approval, the current project extended beyond that approval.Â  There is no record as to the extent of the previous approval.Â Â

I would hold that an action for TRESPASS may be maintained by a homeownersâ€™ association against a resident homeowner in regard to the common elements property.Â  I would rule that an action for VIOLATION OF RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS may be utilized by a homeownersâ€™ association against a resident homeowner in regard to the common elements property.Â  
In my view, the homeownersâ€™ association proved the theories of TRESPASS and VIOLATION OF RESTRICTIVE COVENANTS against the resident homeowners in reference to the common elements property.Â  Accordingly, I VOTE to AFFIRM.

[1] Â For example, Terry Frownfelter, a longtime Cedar Cove resident, acknowledged that many of the residents â€œthat have lived there over the fourteen years that Iâ€™ve been there basically have been able to do what they want to.Â  Iâ€™m thirty feet into the common area myself.â€Â  
[2] The Associationâ€™s final brief refers to the patio as â€œ80% completed when [Rudy] received the [April 8] letter from the Board.â€ The Association characterizes the 80% figure as a concession by the DiPietros.Â  (Respondentâ€™s final brief, 6).
[3] We reach this result without the aid of the settled principle that â€œ[r]estrictive covenants are to be construed most strictly against the grantor and persons seeking [to] enforce them, and liberally in favor of the grantee, all doubts being resolved in favor of a free use property and against restrictions.â€Â  Sprouse v. Winston, 212 S.C. 176, 184, 46 S.E.2d 874, 878 (1948) (quoting 26 C.J.S. Deeds, Â§ 163).

title: State v. Rogers
description: In this criminal matter, appellant appeals the denial of his motion to suppress money evidence, arguing it was obtained as the result of an illegal stop because the authorities did not have reasonable suspicion to stop the vehicle based on a tip received from a confidential informant.
text:
FACTS


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
James E. Rogers, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Williamsburg County
Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4093
Submitted January 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 13, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David Craig Brown, of Florence, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  Appellant, James Rogers, was tried for and convicted of accessory before the fact of armed robbery.Â  He appeals, asserting the trial judge erred in failing to suppress evidence of money found in the back of a police car because it was the fruit of an illegal stop.Â  We affirm.1
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On January 31, 2002, a man with a gun walked into Cash U.S.A., demanded money from the assistant manager of the business, and left with over $1,000.Â  Thereafter, the Williamsburg County Grand Jury indicted Rogers, along with Cortez Brown, Kajuna Mitchum, and Quantrell Wilson, with various offenses concerning the armed robbery at Cash U.S.A.Â  
At the start of the case, Rogers made a pretrial motion to suppress money evidence in this case arguing it was the result of an illegal stop.Â  Rogers asserted the money, found in the back of a police car after he was transported in the car, was fruit of the poisonous tree because the authorities did not have probable cause to stop the vehicle in which Rogers was riding.Â  The trial court held an in camera hearing, at which time the State presented the testimony of Sergeant Shannon Coker with the Kingstree Police Department.Â  
Sergeant Coker testified that around 2:15 p.m. on January 31, he received a call from a confidential informant who was working with the Kingstree Police Department on various cases.Â  He then met with the informant, who told Sergeant Coker about a robbery that was to take place that afternoon at the Cash U.S.A. on Long Street.Â  He told the officer the individuals who would be involved in the armed robbery were James Rogers, Quantrell Wilson, Cortez Brown, and Kajuna Mitchum.Â  The informant also stated the men were supposed to use a white Honda automobile that Rogers had been seen driving.Â  The confidential informant told Sergeant Coker that he heard a conversation regarding the armed robbery that was supposed to take place, including where it would occur, the vehicle used, and the individuals involved.Â  This discussion occurred on the afternoon before the robbery.Â  Sergeant Coker remembered that the informant identified at least one of the co-defendants, Kajuna Mitchum, as having been involved in this conversation.Â  Sergeant Coker testified he had used the confidential informant that provided the information about the robbery numerous times in the past, and the past information he had provided proved to be reliable.Â  
The sergeant called his supervisor and relayed the information he had received.Â  As he was driving the confidential informant home, a call came over the radio indicating there had been an armed robbery at the Cash U.S.A.Â  The officer let the informant out of his vehicle and proceeded to the Pine Avenue area, where Rogers resided.Â  While watching Rogersâ€™ house, he observed a white Honda with four occupants pull up to a stop sign and turn right onto Pine Avenue.Â  The officer pulled in behind the vehicle and recognized it as the vehicle in which Rogers had been seen.Â  Sergeant Coker continued to follow the vehicle until his supervisor and other deputies arrived in the area.Â  He then activated his blue lights.Â  
Rogers exited the passenger side of the vehicle and the officers instructed him to get back into the vehicle.Â  Rogers continued to walk away from the vehicle, and the vehicle â€œtook off,â€ leaving Rogers behind.Â  Cokerâ€™s supervisor dealt with Rogers while the sergeant engaged in a vehicle pursuit of the Honda.Â  
Based on the testimony of Sergeant Coker, the trial judge denied Rogersâ€™ motion to suppress finding that there was reasonable suspicion, â€œbased on sufficient facts to suspect that criminal activity was involved,â€ such that the authorities had a reasonable basis to stop the car.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing a Fourth Amendment search and seizure case, the appellate standard of review is limited to determining whether any evidence supports the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  State v. Missouri, 361 S.C. 107, 111, 603 S.E.2d 594, 596 (2004).Â  The appellate court will reverse only when there is clear error.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Rogers appeals his conviction arguing the trial judge erred in denying his motion to suppress the money found in the back seat of a police car in which he had been transported because it was tainted fruit seized as the result of an illegal stop.Â  We disagree.
The Fourth Amendment guarantees â€œ[t]he right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures.â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV.Â  The stopping of a vehicle and the detention of its occupants constitute a seizure and implicate the Fourth Amendmentâ€™s prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383, 389, 577 S.E.2d 498, 501 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Delaware v. Prouse, 440 U.S. 648, 653-54 (1979)).Â  Our courts have held that in South Carolina, an officer may stop and briefly detain the occupants of a car without treading on Fourth Amendment rights, even without probable cause to arrest, if he has a reasonable suspicion that the occupants are involved in criminal activity.Â  Id.; Sikes v. State, 323 S.C. 28, 30-31, 448 S.E.2d 560, 562 (1994); Knight v. State, 284 S.C. 138, 141, 325 S.E.2d 535, 537 (1985).Â  â€œâ€˜[A] policeman who lacks probable cause but whose observations lead him reasonably to suspect that a particular person has committed, is committing, or is about to commit a crime, may detain that person briefly in order to investigate the circumstances that provoke that suspicion.â€™â€Â  State v. Nelson, 336 S.C. 186, 192, 519 S.E.2d 786, 789 (1999) (quoting Berkemer v. McCarty, 468 U.S. 420, 439 (1984)).Â  
â€œâ€˜Reasonable suspicionâ€™ requires a â€˜particularized and objective basis that would lead one to suspect another of criminal activity.â€™â€Â  State v. Khingratsaiphon, 352 S.C. 62, 69, 572 S.E.2d 456, 459 (2002) (quoting United States v. Cortez, 449 U.S. 411, 418 (1981)).Â  â€œIn determining whether reasonable suspicion exists, â€˜the totality of the circumstances--the whole picture--â€™ must be considered.â€Â  Id.Â  (quoting Cortez, 449 U.S. at 417); see also State v. Woodruff, 344 S.C. 537, 546, 544 S.E.2d 290, 295 (Ct. App. 2001) (â€œThe term â€˜reasonable suspicionâ€™ requires a particularized and objective basis that would lead one to suspect another of criminal activity.Â  In determining whether reasonable suspicion exists, the whole picture must be considered.â€)Â  Reasonable suspicion is something more than an inchoate and unparticularized suspicion or hunch.Â  State v. Butler, 343 S.C. 198, 202, 539 S.E.2d 414, 416 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  However, it is less than the level required for probable cause.Â  Id.  
Rogers contends there were insufficient indicia of reliability of the information provided by the confidential informant for the police to make an investigatory stop.Â  Accordingly, Rogers maintains the stop was improper, and the trial judge therefore erred in allowing the introduction of any evidence as a result of the investigatory stop.Â  We disagree.
In making his argument, Rogers relies on the case of State v. Green, 341 S.C. 214, 532 S.E.2d 896 (Ct. App. 2000), which relied on the case of Florida v. J.L., 529 U.S. 266 (2000), both of which held an anonymous tip provided insufficient indicia of reliability to justify an investigatory stop.Â  We find Green and J.L. clearly distinguishable from the case at hand.Â  Both Green and J.L. involved investigatory stops based on anonymous tips, wherein the courts found the anonymous tips provided insufficient indicia of reliability to make an investigatory stop.Â  Here, on the other hand, the tip was provided, not by an anonymous tipster, but a known confidential informant, whom the officers had used numerous times in the past and whose information had proved to be reliable.Â  In J.L., the United States Supreme Court noted, â€œUnlike a tip from a known informant whose reputation can be assessed and who can be held responsible if her allegations turn out to be fabricated, an anonymous tip alone seldom demonstrates the informantâ€™s basis of knowledge or veracity.â€Â  J.L., 529 U.S. at 270 (citations omitted).Â  In Green, this court, citing to J.L., stated as follows:

The only information available to the officer was the statement of an unknown, unaccountable informant who neither explained how he knew about the money and narcotics, nor supplied any basis for the officer to believe he had inside information about Green.Â  Since the telephone call was anonymous, the caller did not place his credibility at risk and could lie with impunity.Â  Therefore, we cannot judge the credibility of the caller, and the risk of fabrication becomes unacceptable.

Green, 341 S.C. at 218, 532 S.E.2d at 898 (citations omitted).
In the case at hand, the officer received the information from a known, accountable informant whose reputation could be assessed and who explained how he knew about the planned robbery, thereby supplying a basis, outside of his already proven reliability, for Sergeant Coker to believe the confidential informant had inside information on the matter.Â  
We further note, this case is distinguishable from Green and J.L. in that, at the time of the investigatory stop here, the officers knew that a crime had, in fact, already occurred.Â  Here, the officers were not investigating the possibility that a crime may be occurring, but were investigating a crime that had occurred and had been independently reported.
The record shows a known and reliable informant provided Sergeant Coker with the names of four persons, including Rogers, that were planning to commit an armed robbery at the Cash U.S.A. on Long Street that afternoon, and indicated the men planned to use a white Honda automobile that Rogers had been seen driving.Â  When Sergeant Coker received information that the robbery had just occurred, he drove to the area where Rogers lived, watched Rogersâ€™ house, and observed a white Honda with four occupants, the same number of people that the informant reported were to be involved in the robbery.Â  As he pulled in behind the Honda, he recognized the vehicle as the one â€œRogers had been in or had been seen to be in.â€Â  Under the totality of the circumstances, we hold Officer Coker had a particularized and objective basis that would lead Sergeant Coker to suspect the occupants of the Honda had committed a crime such that reasonable suspicion existed to justify the investigatory stop.Â  Accordingly, there is evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s findings and we find no error.Â  
For the foregoing reasons, Rogersâ€™ conviction isÂ Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

1 We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

In re Terrence M
