THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        In the Interest of Terrence M., a Juvenile under the age of Seventeen, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â FrancesÂ  P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4097
Heard March 8, 2006 â€“ Filed March 16, 2006

REVERSED and REMANDED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General David A. Spencer, Office of the Attorney General; all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph E. Hoisington, Â of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: The State of South Carolina appeals from a family court order in which the court found it did not have jurisdiction to order a juvenile to pay restitution because the juvenile was no longer on probation.Â  The State argues the family court erred in concluding the juvenileâ€™s probation ended when he was committed for an entirely separate crime.Â  We reverse and remand for a de novo hearing. 
FACTS
On November 21, 2002, Terrence M. was adjudicated delinquent for possession of a stolen motor vehicle, failure to stop for a blue light, and probation violation.Â  Prior to making a final disposition, the family court sent Terrence to the Coastal Evaluation Center.Â  After Terrence was evaluated, the family court sentenced him to be committed to the Department of Juvenile Justice for an indeterminate period not to exceed his twenty-first birthday, suspended upon alternative placement and probation for an indefinite period.Â  The family court reserved the issue of restitution at that time.[1] 
At some point thereafter, the State informed Terrence of the amount the victim sought in restitution.Â  Terrence never agreed to the amount, and no restitution hearing was set. 
In 2004, Terrence was charged with possession of crack and disturbing schools. The possession of crack charge was dismissed without prosecution, and Terrence admitted to disturbing schools.Â  He also admitted he was in contempt of court for failing to comply with his home detention agreement.Â Â Â  Terrence was adjudicated delinquent and ultimately committed to the Department of Juvenile Justice (DJJ) for an indeterminate period not to exceed his twenty-first birthday. In the commitment order, the family court also directed the solicitorâ€™s office to schedule a restitution hearing to determine restitution owed on the 2002 possession of a stolen motor vehicle charge.Â  
On January 20, 2005, a restitution hearing was finally held. By this time, Terrence had been released from DJJ, was no longer on parole for his 2004 adjudication, and was incarcerated as an adult.Â  Prior to the restitution hearing, Terrence argued the family court lacked jurisdiction to order restitution because he was no longer on probation.Â  The family court initially disagreed, held the restitution hearing, and ordered Terrence to pay $1,184.62 in restitution.[2] Terrence simultaneously filed a notice of appeal and made a motion for reconsideration, reiterating his argument regarding jurisdiction.Â  Ultimately, the family court agreed, finding that because Terrence was no longer on probation, it did not have jurisdiction to order restitution.Â  This appeal followed. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Both parties agree there is no statutory authority for the family court to impose restitution except as a condition of probation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-7805(A)(3) (Supp. 2005) (â€œ[T]he court may impose monetary restitution . . . as a condition of probation.â€).Â  However, the State argues Terrenceâ€™s 2002 probationary sentence for an â€œindefinite periodâ€ had not terminated at the time of the restitution hearing.Â  We agree.
The family court has the authority to place a child on probation for a period of time not to exceed the childâ€™s eighteenth birthday. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-7805(A)(3) (Supp. 2005). â€œA child placed on probation by the court remains under the authority of the court only until the expiration of the specified term of the childâ€™s probation.â€Â  Id.Â Â  
In 2002, Terrence was placed on probation for an indefinite period. Two years after being placed on probation, Terrence was committed to DJJ on new charges.Â  Although we recognize the practical difficulty Terrenceâ€™s probation officer would have had supervising Terrence during his commitment, we cannot ignore the lack of a family court order revoking Terrenceâ€™s probation.Â  Because Terrenceâ€™s probation was never revoked and Terrence has not yet attained the age of eighteen, the language of section 20-7-7805(A)(3) constrains us to find his sentence of indefinite probation continued even after being committed to DJJ.Â Â  Thus, the family court had jurisdiction to order restitution on January 20, 2005.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family court rescinding its previous order of restitution is reversed.Â  In fairness to Terrence, who never had the opportunity to appeal from the family courtâ€™s initial order setting the amount of restitution, we decline to reinstate that order and instead remand this case for a de novo restitution hearing.
REVERSED and REMANDED.
ANDERSON and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] Restitution was sought because of damage to the stolen car.
[2] After ordering restitution, there was some confusion regarding which agency would be responsible for monitoring the case.Â  A representative from DJJ stated that Terrenceâ€™s probation ended once he was committed, and since then, his parole had ended from the crime for which he was committed.Â  According to the representative, DJJ had no jurisdiction over Terrence because he was no longer on probation or parole.Â  To circumvent that problem, the court ordered the solicitorâ€™s office to track Terrenceâ€™s restitution payments, and in the event Terrence failed to pay, the solicitorâ€™s office could file a contempt of court charge.

title: City of Aiken v. Koontz
description: In this criminal case, appellant was convicted in abstentia.  Appellant contends the trial court committed reversible error in failing to make factual findings on two issues: (1) whether appellant had notice of the trial; and (2) whether appellant was warned that the trial would proceed in his absence.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
City of Aiken, Respondent,
v.
David Michael Koontz, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4094
Submitted March 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Leon E. Green, of Aiken, for Appellant.
City Solicitor Richard L. Pearce, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â David Michael Koontz was tried in absentia and without counsel.Â  He was convicted of driving under suspension (DUS), third offense.Â  The trial judge sentenced him to six months and a $2,100 fine.Â  On appeal, Koontz argues the trial judge erred in proceeding with his trial in absentia.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On May 8, 2004, Koontz drove his children to the public safety headquarters to deliver them to his wife, from whom he was separated.Â  As Koontz drove up, his wife informed Aiken Department of Public Safety Officer Edgar Gonzalez that Koontz should not be driving because his license was suspended.Â  Officer Gonzalez observed Koontz driving a Dodge truck and verified with dispatch that Koontzâ€™s license was suspended.Â  He arrested Koontz for DUS, third offense.
Koontz was charged with DUS, third offense, by South Carolina Uniform Traffic Ticket #70962CT.Â  The traffic ticket set a trial date for June 28, 2004.Â  Between May 8, 2004 and June 28, 2004, Koontz hired an attorney to represent him.Â  In defense counselâ€™s June 25, 2004 notice of representation letter, he notified the municipal judge he was representing Koontz, requested a jury trial, and asked that he be informed of all court dates.Â  The trial was continued from June 28 to another date.Â  Defense counsel was informed of the August 3, September 21, and October 19, 2004, Aiken Municipal Court jury terms.
On October 19, at the start of the October term of jury trials, defense counsel petitioned the municipal court judge to be relieved as attorney for Koontz due to Koontzâ€™s failure to: (1) respond to his phone calls; (2) pay him; and (3) otherwise aid in the defense preparation.Â  The Aiken City Solicitor informed the trial judge that defense counsel attended roll call on October 19, 2004 and â€œindicated that he had notified [Koontz] to be here and that he was going to be relieved as his attorney.â€Â  In his motion to be relieved, defense counsel declared: â€œUpon being notified that [Koontzâ€™s] case was on the trial roster for the week of October 18, [defense counsel] sent [Koontz] notice of his trial at the address provided by [Koontz].â€Â  Koontz did not contact his attorney, the city solicitor, or the municipal judge and did not show up for roll call or jury selection.Â  Defense counsel was relieved from further representation of Koontz on October 19, the same day as roll call and jury selection for Koontzâ€™s trial.
On October 20, 2004, Koontz was tried in his absence for DUS, third offense.Â  The jury found Koontz guilty as charged.
Koontz received notice of his conviction the same day.Â  On October 26, 2004, Koontz filed an appeal with the circuit court.Â  Koontz alleged he was entitled to a new trial because he did not receive notice of the trial date and due process was denied him because he was not given the opportunity to defend himself at trial.Â  The circuit judge affirmed the conviction and sentence.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal appeals from municipal court, the circuit court does not conduct a de novo review, but instead reviews for preserved error raised to it by appropriate exception.Â  State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Henderson, 347 S.C. 455, 556 S.E.2d 691 (Ct. App. 2001); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-25-105 (Supp. 2005) (â€œThere shall be no trial de novo on any appeal from a municipal court.â€).Â  The appellate court reviewing the criminal appeal from the circuit court may review for errors of law only.Â  State v. Cutter, 261 S.C. 140, 199 S.E.2d 61 (1973); Henderson, 347 S.C. at 457, 556 S.E.2d at 692.Â  In criminal cases, the court of appeals sits to review errors of law only and is bound by the factual findings of the trial court unless clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 625 S.E.2d 239 (Ct. App. 2006); Landis, 362 S.C. at 101, 606 S.E.2d at 505.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Koontz asserts the trial court â€œcommit[ted] reversible error when it tried [Koontz] in his absence and did not make a factual finding on the issue of whether [Koontz] received notice of the trial.â€Â  Additionally, Koontz contends â€œthere was no finding of fact by the presiding judge that [Koontz] had in fact waived his right to be present for his trial.â€Â  We disagree.
A criminal defendant has a constitutional right guaranteed by the Confrontation Clause of the Sixth Amendment to be present at trial.Â  See U.S. Const. amend. VI; Illinois v. Allen, 397 U.S. 337, 338 (1970) (â€œOne of the most basic of the rights guaranteed by the Confrontation Clause is the accusedâ€™s right to be present in the courtroom at every stage of his trial.â€).Â  However, Rule 16, SCRCrimP provides:

Except in cases wherein capital punishment is a permissible sentence, a person indicted for misdemeanors and/or felonies may voluntarily waive his right to be present and may be tried in his absence upon a finding by the court that such person has received notice of his right to be present and that a warning was given that the trial would proceed in his absence upon a failure to attend the court.

Thus, it is well established that a defendant may be tried in his absence.Â  State v. Thompson, 355 S.C. 255, 584 S.E.2d 131 (Ct. App. 2003).
While Rule 16 permits a knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to be present, such a waiver is permitted only in limited circumstances.Â  State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 625 S.E.2d 239 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  In order for a criminal defendant to be tried in absentia, certain requirements must first be met.Â  State v. Truesdale, 345 S.C. 542, 548 S.E.2d 896 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  A trial judge must determine a defendant voluntarily waived his right to be present at trial in order to try the case in absentia.Â  State v. Ritch, 292 S.C. 75, 354 S.E.2d 909 (1987); State v. Jackson, 288 S.C. 94, 341 S.E.2d 375 (1986); Truesdale, 345 S.C. at 549 n.5, 548 S.E.2d at 899 n.5; State v. Castineira, 341 S.C. 619, 535 S.E.2d 449 (Ct. App. 2000), affâ€™d, 351 S.C. 635, 572 S.E.2d 263 (2002).Â  Additionally, the trial judge must make findings of fact on the record that the defendant (1) received notice of his right to be present; and (2) was warned that the trial would proceed in his absence should he fail to attend.Â  Jackson, 288 S.C. at 96, 341 S.E.2d at 375; Castineira, 341 S.C. at 623, 535 S.E.2d at 451.
Notice of the term of court for which the trial is set constitutes sufficient notice to enable a criminal defendant to make an effective waiver of his right to be present.Â  State v. Jackson, 290 S.C. 435, 351 S.E.2d 167 (1986); Ellis v. State, 267 S.C. 257, 227 S.E.2d 304 (1976); see also State v. Goode, 299 S.C. 479, 385 S.E.2d 844 (1989) (stating general notice given by courts of general session as to which term an individual will be tried in is sufficient to enable that individual to effectively waive his right to be present).Â  If the record, however, does not include evidence to support a finding that the defendant was afforded notice of his trial, the resulting conviction in absentia cannot stand.Â  Jackson, 290 S.C. at 436, 351 S.E.2d at 167.
When Koontz posted bond on May 9, 2004, the day after his arrest, he was provided an order specifying methods and conditions of release.Â  The order contained, in Paragraph 3, the following language:

3.Â  That the defendant shall appear at . . . the session of . . . municipal . . . court beginning on . . . 6-28-04 at . . . 8:30 oâ€™clock, A.M., at . . . 251 Laurens Street, Aiken, SCÂ  29801.Â  If no final disposition is made during that session, the defendant shall appear at such other times and places as ordered by the court.Â  (Emphasis added).

Koontz specifically initialed this paragraph, which is highlighted on the form by being enclosed in a box. This form contained an â€œAcknowledgement by Defendant,â€ which read: â€œI understand and have been informed that I have a right and obligation to be present at trial and should I fail to attend the court, the trial will proceed in my absence.â€Â  Koontz signed his name at the bottom of this form.
On the â€œChecklist for Magistrates and Municipal Judgesâ€ dated May 9, 2004, the judge noted that Koontz â€œwas informed . . . [of] [h]is right and obligation to be present at trial and that trial will proceed in his absence if he fails to attend.â€
On October 19, prior to jury selection, the judge asked: â€œIs [Koontz] here?â€Â  The city solicitor responded: â€œNo sir, Judge. His lawyer appeared and he has a motion on your desk to be relieved as his counsel. We are ready to proceed with the trial in his absence.â€Â  After the jury was selected and the trial was about to begin on October 20, the judge reviewed Koontzâ€™s absence from the courtroom.Â  He advised the jury of Koontzâ€™s legal rights and that Koontz was given notice of his right to be present at trial.Â  The judge noted: â€œJust for a moment to revisit what I told you all last night Mr. Koontz was given a summons and notice to appear yesterday afternoon.â€
According to defense counsel, Koontz was aware of the October 19 jury trial term and the need for him to be present for roll call and trial.Â  Koontz was on notice early in the process of his need to be at each term of municipal court.Â  More importantly, his retained attorney notified him of the October term when his case was going to be tried.
The record is replete with Koontzâ€™s notices to be in court for his trial.Â  He was warned that a failure to appear would result in a trial in his absence and signed a statement that he understood that warning and his obligations.Â  The City complied with Koontzâ€™s request for a jury trial and his request to be notified of his court dates through his attorney.Â  Koontzâ€™s case was not tried at two city court jury terms, August and September, instead being held over to the October term.Â  Koontz was given ample opportunity to defend himself at trial but he failed to appear for roll call or the trial itself, even after being notified of his trial date by his attorney.Â  He made no effort to contact the City or the court to inform them that defense counsel was no longer his attorney and that further notices should be sent to him personally or to request an extension after his attorney petitioned to be and was relieved from representation.
The municipal judge fully complied with the mandates of Rule 16, SCRCrimP.Â  The trial court correctly proceeded with a trial in Koontzâ€™s absence after making appropriate factual findings on the issue of whether Koontz had notice of the trial and whether he was warned the trial would proceed in his absence.Â  Further, Koontzâ€™s former attorney noted that Koontz had received the proper notice.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, Koontzâ€™s conviction and sentence are
AFFIRMED.
 HEARN, C.J. and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

title: Garnett v. WRP Enterprises
description: Cindy Barrett Garnett brought this declaratory judgment action to determine the amount of liability coverage available to a Thrifty Car Rental customer who collided with a vehicle in which Garnett was riding.  Philadelphia Indemnity Insurance Co. appeals from the trial court's ruling that limits in excess of the statutory minimum applied.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Cindy Barrett Garnett, Plaintiff,
v.
WRP Enterprises, Inc. & Revmax, Inc. d/b/a Thrifty Car Rental, and Philadelphia Indemnity Insurance Company,
Defendants,
Of whom Philadelphia Indemnity Insurance Company is the,
Appellant,
and Cindy Barrett Garnett, WRP Enterprises, Inc. &
Revmax, Inc. d/b/a Thrifty Car Rental are the, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Clifton Newman, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4095
Submitted February 1, 2006 â€“ Filed March 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James Edward Bradley, of West Columbia, and James E. Green, Jr. and Mark E. Dreyer, both of Tulsa, Oklahoma, for Appellant.
Nelson Russell Parker, of Manning, and William Pearce Davis, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  Cindy Barrett Garnett brought this declaratory judgment action to determine the amount of liability insurance available to a Thrifty Car Rental customer who collided with a vehicle in which Garnett was riding.Â  The trial court found Philadelphia Indemnity Insurance Co.,[1] the rental companyâ€™s commercial liability carrier, was responsible for coverage.Â  Philadelphia appeals, arguing the trial court erred in interpreting the clear terms of the insurance policy, in failing to consider the entire contract, and in ignoring relevant parol evidence in the event the contract is deemed ambiguous.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
At the time this action arose in 1999, WRP Enterprises, Inc. and Revmax, Inc., d/b/a Thrifty Car Rental, (collectively, â€œThriftyâ€) owned and operated a Thrifty Car Rental agency in Savannah, Georgia.Â Â Â  
Thrifty purchased a commercial lines insurance policy from Philadelphia Indemnity Insurance Company that provided liability coverage for their rental vehicles for the period of June 1, 1999 to June 1, 2000.Â  The policy contains a â€œDual Interest Endorsement,â€ which provides for differing rates of liability coverage depending on the amount of insurance provided by the automobile rental contract:

It is hereby understood and agreed that Item Two â€“ â€œSchedule of Coverages and Covered Autos â€“ Liability Limit, The most we will payâ€ of the Business Auto Coverage Form Declarations is amended to read as follows:
  
When the Insuredâ€™s rental contract provides the renter with minimum state financial responsibility limits, the following limits of liability are applicable to this policy:

  
    
      Bodily Injury
        Liability   
       $15,000.00Â  each person
    
    
       
      
    
    
      
       $30,000.00 each accident
    
    
       
      
    
    
      Property Damage
        Liability  
       $10,000.00 each accident
    
    
      
      
    
  

  
When the rental contract provide[s] the renter with limits in excess of the minimum state financial responsibility laws, the following limits of liability are applicable to this policy:

  
    
      
        Bodily Injury
          Liability  
         $100,000.00Â  each person
      
      
         
        
      
      
        
         $300,000.00Â  each accident
      
      
         
        
      
      
        Property Damage
          Liability 
         $50,000.00 Â Â  each
          accident
      
    
  


On or about July 10, 1999, while this policy was in effect, Bierdie L. Williams rented a car from Thrifty in Savannah, Georgia.Â  Williamsâ€™s rental contract indicates that she purchased optional Supplemental Liability Insurance (SLI) coverage and paid a daily premium of $8.95.Â  This premium was to provide Williams with excess liability coverage against third-party claims up to a limit of $1,000,000; it was supplemental coverage for the difference between the amount under the state minimum financial responsibility law and $1,000,000.[3]Â  
While driving the Thrifty rental car in South Carolina, Williams struck a vehicle in which Garnett was a passenger.Â  Garnett subsequently brought an action against Williams for injuries she allegedly sustained in the accident.Â Â Â  
Garnett brought this declaratory judgment action against Thrifty and Philadelphia, seeking a determination of the amount of liability insurance coverage available on Williamsâ€™s rental vehicle.Â  Philadelphia contended only the minimum limits of $15,000/$30,000/$10,000 (i.e., $15,000 bodily injury per person, $30,000 bodily injury per accident, and $10,000 property damage per accident) are available to Williams.Â  Thrifty contended that, pursuant to the Dual Interest Endorsement, Williams was entitled to liability limits of $100,000/$300,000/$50,000 because the rental contract provided for limits in excess of the minimum state financial responsibility law.Â  Both Philadelphia and Thrifty moved for summary judgment.
The trial court granted Thriftyâ€™s motion for summary judgment, finding the unambiguous terms of the insurance policy mandated the higher limits of coverage.Â  The court ruled the rental contract between Thrifty and Williams provided for coverage over the minimum imposed by the state financial responsibility law, thus invoking the higher coverage of $100,000/$300,000/$50,000 pursuant to the Dual Interest Endorsement in the Philadelphia policy that insured Thrifty.Â  Philadelphia appeals.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying issue.â€[4]Â  An action to construe a contract is at law.[5]Â  In an action at law, the trial court must be affirmed when there is â€œany evidenceâ€ to support the courtâ€™s findings.[6]Â  
Under the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, summary judgment is appropriate â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€[7]Â  
â€œWhen reviewing the grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard applied by the trial court pursuant to Rule 56(c), SCRCP.â€[8]Â  â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€[9]Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Philadelphia argues the trial court erred in finding it is required to provide coverage of $100,000/$300,000/$50,000 on the rental vehicle.Â  Philadelphia asserts the court erred in interpreting the clear terms of the insurance policy, in failing to consider the entire contract, and in ignoring relevant parol evidence in the event the contract is deemed ambiguous.Â  We disagree.
â€œUnless the parties agree to a different rule, the validity and interpretation of a contract is ordinarily to be determined by the law of the state in which the contract was made.â€[10]Â  In the case before us, the trial court found the vehicle rental was entered into in Georgia; therefore, Georgia law applies.[11]Â  
â€œUnder Georgia law, contracts of insurance are interpreted by ordinary rules of contract construction.â€[12]Â  â€œ â€˜Three well known rules . . . apply.Â  Any ambiguities in the contract are strictly construed against the insurer as drafter of the document; any exclusion from coverage sought to be invoked by the insurer is likewise strictly construed; and insurance contracts are to be read in accordance with the reasonable expectations of the insured where possible.â€™ â€[13]Â  â€œWhere the terms are clear and unambiguous, and capable of only one reasonable interpretation, the court is to look to the contract alone to ascertain the partiesâ€™ intent.â€[14]Â  
Philadelphia asserts the higher limits of coverage in the Dual Interest Endorsement are not triggered here because the rental contract â€œclearlyâ€ states that the SLI is to be provided under a â€œseparate policyâ€; therefore, excess coverage was not provided for in the rental contract itself.Â  Alternatively, Philadelphia asserts that it is undisputed that, at the time Williams executed the rental contract, Thrifty did not maintain an SLI policy with Philadelphia or any other carrier.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
We find no error in the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  The Dual Interest Endorsement provision clearly and unambiguously states that â€œ[w]hen the Insuredâ€™s rental contract provide[s] the renter with limits in excess of the minimum state financial responsibility laws,â€ the bodily injury limits are $100,000 for each person and $300,000 for each accident, and the property damage limit is $50,000 per accident.Â  [Emphasis added.]Â  The rental contract in this case provides that renters who accept SLI coverage for an additional daily charge are â€œentitled toâ€ protection against third party liability claims equal to the minimum limits in Georgia, â€œand [ ] SLI provides [the renter] with a separate policy providing excess coverageâ€ up to $1,000,000.Â Â Â  
Williams accepted and paid for SLI from Thrifty; thus, Thrifty, through the rental contract, agreed to provide Williams with limits in excess of the minimum state financial responsibility law.Â  The fact that the rental contract states a separate policy is the source of the insurance does not negate the fact that the rental contract was the mechanism by which Thrifty became obligated to provide additional coverage.Â  Further, although Thrifty admits its employee was not authorized to sell SLI because Thrifty did not have a carrier for a policy at that time, this does not change our analysis.Â  Thrifty obligated itself to provide supplemental coverage, regardless of whether it was through an insurance policy or out-of-pocket.Â  Thriftyâ€™s counsel acknowledged this point at the hearing:Â  â€œ[T]here is no question but having sold [Williams] that coverage, we must provide it.Â  . . .Â  [T]he rental contract provides that sheâ€™s purchased a million dollars in single limit coverage . . . [a]nd she paid for it.Â  So there is no question but that itâ€™s there.â€Â  Thus, regardless of the source of the coverage, Thriftyâ€™s rental contract with its customer does, on its face, provide for coverage in excess of the minimum financial responsibility law.Â  This, in turn, triggers the higher coverage in the policy Thrifty carried with Philadelphia on its fleet of vehicles.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not err in holding Philadelphia is responsible for providing coverage on the rental vehicle of up to $100,000/$300,000/$50,000. [15] Â  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] Philadelphia Indemnity Insurance Company is also referred to as the â€œPhiladelphia Insurance Companyâ€ in some of the trial records, but all parties state in their briefs that this is a misnomer.Â  Further, Philadelphia Indemnity Insurance Company is the name listed on the insurance policy that is the subject of this appeal.Â  
[2]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â  Section 10(A)(1) and (2) of Williamsâ€™s rental contract provided the following regarding SLI coverage:

10.Â  OPTIONAL SUPPLEMENTAL LIABILITY INSURANCE (WHERE AVAILABLE).
A.Â  Where available, and for an additional daily charge, if I have initialed that I accept the optional SLI at the beginning of the rental, I am entitled to the following:
  
1.Â  Thrifty will protect Me against third-party liability claims arising out of the use or operation of the Car for (i) bodily injury or death of another (excluding any of My or Additional Renterâ€™s family members related by blood or marriage or adoption residing with Me or them) and (ii) Property damage other than to the Car.Â  This protection is limited to an amount equal to the minimum limits specified by the compulsory insurance or financial responsibility laws relating to automobile liability insurance in the state in which the Car is rented and shall be referred to as Primary Protection; and,
2.Â  SLI provides Me with a separate policy providing excess coverage against such claims for the difference between the Primary Protection and a maximum combined single limit of $1,000,000 (U.S.) per occurrence for bodily injury, including death and property damage, for other than the Car while the Car is on rent to Me.Â  
  

[4]Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).
[5]Â  Id.Â  
[6]Â  Id. (citing Townes Assocs. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976)).
[7]Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP.
[8]Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002); see also Baird v. Charleston County, 333 S.C. 519, 529, 511 S.E.2d 69, 74 (1999) (â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€).Â  
[9]Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997).
[10]Â  Unisun Ins. Co. v. Hertz Rental Corp., 312 S.C. 549, 551-52, 436 S.E.2d 182, 184 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
[11]Â  No one disputes the courtâ€™s determination that Georgia law applies.Â  We note, however, as did the trial court, that Georgia and South Carolina law regarding the interpretation of a contract are virtually identical.Â  Thus, if South Carolina law applied, the analysis would be the same.Â Â  
[12] Â Boardman Petroleum, Inc. v. Federated Mut. Ins. Co., 498 S.E.2d 492, 494 (Ga. 1998).Â  
[13]Â  Id. (quoting Richards v. Hanover Ins. Co., 299 S.E.2d 561, 563 (Ga. 1983)) (citations omitted in original).
[14]Â  Id.
[15]Â  Having found there is no ambiguity in the provisions in question, we need not address Philadelphiaâ€™s remaining argument in this regard.

title: Auto-Owners Insurance v. Hamin
description: This is a declaratory judgment action by a homeowner contesting insurer's denial of a fire loss claim under an intentional acts exclusion.
text:
Auto-Owners v. Hamin


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Auto-Owners Insurance Company, Respondent,
v.
Darnasai Hamin and Vermelle Simmons, her Conservator,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4096
Heard February 8, 2006 â€“ Filed March 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Michael Stuart Davenport, of Wilmington, NC, and Shannon Lee Felder, of Columbia, for Appellants.Â  
Thomas E. Player, Jr., of Sumter, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Darnasai Hamin appeals a circuit court order finding Auto-Owners Insurance Company not liable to provide coverage under Haminâ€™s homeownersâ€™ insurance policy for a fire that occurred in her home.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Hamin, a minor, owns a house insured by Auto-Owners.Â  Numerous family members reside in the house including Haminâ€™s mother, Melissa Stinnett, Haminâ€™s sister, Vermica Grant, two other siblings, and Haminâ€™s conservator and grandmother, Vermelle Simmons.Â  
At the time of the fire, Grant was fifteen years old.Â  A few hours before the fire, Grant returned to the house after an unexplained absence.Â  Upon her return, Stinnett and Grant argued.Â  Stinnett threatened to place Grant in the custody of the Department of Juvenile Justice if she continued her behavior.Â  Grant replied that if she had to leave the house, she would see that â€œnobody lived in the house.â€ Â 
Later that night, the house was severely damaged in a fire.Â  Grant admitted she started the fire.Â  Grant stated she did so because she was upset with her mother, was jealous of her infant brother, and wanted to get her motherâ€™s attention.Â  Grant alleged she did not believe the house would ignite.Â  After its investigation, Auto-Owners concluded Grant started the fire by pouring gasoline in the basement and then lighting a piece of paper.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Auto-Owners filed this declaratory judgment action alleging the policyâ€™s intentional loss exclusion barred the claim.Â  The exclusion prevents coverage for any loss â€œcaused directly or indirectly by . . . [a]n action by or at the direction of any insured committed with the intent to cause a loss.â€ Â The policy defines insured as â€œyou, your relatives; and any other person under the age of 21 residing with you who is in your care or the care of a relative.â€Â  
Hamin moved for summary judgment or, in the alternative, a judicial finding of coverage.Â  Hamin argued, inter alia, Grant was not an â€œinsuredâ€ under the policy because she possessed no insurable interest in the house, and the phrase â€œintent to cause a lossâ€ in the policy was ambiguous.Â  
The circuit court denied Haminâ€™s motion for summary judgment and found no coverage.Â  The court reasoned Grant was an insured and her lack of an insurable interest in the property was immaterial. Â Further, the court held the phrase â€œintent to cause a lossâ€ was not ambiguous and found Grant intended to cause a loss when she set the fire.Â  Finally, the court held a malicious mischief provision of the policy did not provide coverage.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Declaratory judgment actions are neither legal nor
equitable, and therefore, the standard of review depends on the nature of the underlying issues.Â  Campbell v. Marion County Hosp. Dist., 354 S.C. 274, 279, 580 S.E.2d 163, 165 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  When the purpose of the underlying dispute is to determine whether coverage exists under an insurance policy, the action is one at law.Â  Horry County v. Ins. Reserve Fund, 344 S.C. 493, 497, 544 S.E.2d 637, 639-640 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  In an action at law tried without a jury, the appellate court will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless they are found to be without evidence that reasonably supports those findings.Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Insurable Interest
Hamin contends Grant was not an insured under the policy because Grant had no insurable interest in the house.Â  We disagree.
The policy defines an â€œinsuredâ€ as â€œyou, your relatives; and any other person under the age of 21 residing with you who is in your care or the care of a relative.â€Â  Under the plain terms of the policy, Grant was an insured as she is Haminâ€™s relative and a resident of the household.Â  In South Carolina Farm Bureau Mutual Insurance Co. v. Kelly, this court found the policy definition of â€œinsuredâ€ rendered the issue of whether the adult son had an insurable interest immaterial because the adult son was a relative and lived in the house, and thus was an insured under the policy.Â  345 S.C. 232, 240, 547 S.E.2d 871, 875 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  We likewise find the issue of whether Grant possessed an insurable interest immaterial because Grant is an insured under the terms of the policy.Â  See Pennell v. Foster, 338 S.C. 9, 18, 524 S.E.2d 630, 634 (Ct. App. 1999) (stating the terms of the policy govern the scope of the coverage, unless in conflict with statutory requirements). 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Ambiguity in the Intentional Loss Exclusion
Hamin also argues the phrase â€œintent to cause a lossâ€ in the intentional loss exclusion of the policy is ambiguous.Â  Again applying Kelly, we find no ambiguity.[1]Â  
In Kelly, the insurer initiated an action to recover money for two claims previously paid to the insured after the insuredâ€™s adult son confessed to starting the fires.Â  Kelly, 345 at 235-36, 547 S.E.2d at 873.Â  The intentional acts exclusion in Kelly mirrored the exclusion in this case, providing the insurer does â€œnot insure for loss caused directly or indirectly . . . out of any act committed by any insured with the intent to cause a loss.â€Â  Id. at 241, 547 S.E.2d at 876.Â  The Kelly court held the language clear and unambiguous.Â  Id.Â  We likewise find no ambiguity.[2]
III.Â Â Â  Capacity to Form IntentÂ  
Hamin next argues Grant did not have the mental or legal capacity to form the intent to cause a loss.Â  This argument was not ruled upon by the circuit court and, therefore, is not preserved for appeal.Â  See Harris v. Bennett, 332 S.C. 238, 245, 503 S.E.2d 782, 786 (Ct. App. 1998) (stating an issue must have been raised to and ruled upon by the circuit court to be preserved for appellate review).Â  
IV.Â Â Â  Public Policy
Lastly, Hamin contends public policy considerations prevent enforcement of the intentional loss exclusion.Â  This issue, having not been ruled upon by the circuit court, is not preserved.Â  Id.Â  
AFFIRMED.
 GOOLSBY and HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Because we find the exclusion unambiguous, we find no merit to Haminâ€™s argument that we must apply the malicious mischief provision to interpret the meaning of the exclusion.Â  See Sphere Drake Ins. Co. v. Litchfield, 313 S.C. 471, 474, 438 S.E.2d 275, 277 (Ct. App. 1993) (â€œWhile a policy should be liberally construed in favor of coverage and against exclusion, courts are not permitted to torture the ordinary meaning of language to extend coverage expressly excluded by the terms of the policy.â€).
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We need not apply the Miller two-prong test of intent because the circuit court never explicitly ruled on the second prong of the test, and the parties neither argued the Miller test in their briefs nor raised the issue on appeal until their reply argument before this court.Â  See Miller v. Fidelity-Phoenix Ins. Co., 268 S.C. 72, 75, 231 S.E.2d 701, 702 (1977) (explaining the two prongs of the test as:Â  1) whether the act causing the loss was intentional, and 2) whether the result of the act was intended).Â  Therefore, the issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See Hunter v. Staples, 335 S.C. 93, 103, 515 S.E.2d 261, 267 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review); Continental Ins. Co. v. Shives, 328 S.C. 470, 474, 492 S.E.2d 808, 811 (Ct. App. 1997) (An appellant may not use the reply brief to argue issues not raised in the initial brief.).

title: Proctor v. DHEC
description: The Respondent, Doug Proctor d/b/a Anderson Tire Recycling, brought a tort action for gross negligence against the Appellant, Department of Health and Environmental Control, under section 15-78-60(12) of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.  The Appellant answered and pled numerous defenses as to subsections (1), (2), (3), (4), (5) and/or (13) of section 15-78-60.  The jury awarded the Respondent $688,503.  Pursuant to section 15-78-120(a)(1), the trial court reduced the jury verdict award to $300,000.  A plethora of issues are presented on appeal: (1) did the Respondent prove gross negligence under section 15-78-60(12); (2) did the trial court err in denying DHECâ€™s motion for directed verdict, motion for JNOV and/or motion for a new trial; (3) did the trial court err in allowing evidence of events prior to the Boardâ€™s 2000 order; (4) did the trial court err in charging the jury as to lost profits; (5) did the trial court err in failing to charge the jury as to subsections (1), (2), (3), (4), (5) and/or (13) of section 15-78-60; (6) did the trial court err in refusing DHECâ€™s request to limit Respondentâ€™s damages to $9,500; and (7)	was the amount of damages so unduly liberal or grossly excessive as to require a new trial absolute or a new trial nisi remittitur.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Doug Proctor d/b/a Anderson Tire Recycling, Respondent,
v.
Department of Health and Environmental Control,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Anderson County
Â Alexander S. Macaulay, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4098
Heard March 8, 2006 â€“ Filed March 20, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James W. Logan, Jr. and Stacey T. Coffee, of Anderson, for Appellant.
Jeffrey Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.:Â  A jury rendered a $688,503 verdict for Doug Proctor d/b/a Anderson Tire Recycling (Proctor) against the Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC).Â  The circuit judge reduced the award to $300,000 pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-120(a)(1).Â  DHEC contends Proctor failed to prove gross negligence; the trial court incorrectly charged the jury; and the damages awarded were so unduly liberal or grossly excessive as to require a new trial.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Proctor owns and operates a waste tire processing and disposal facility in Anderson County, South Carolina.Â  South Carolina law endows DHEC with the authority to issue permits to waste tire facilities.Â  In 1993, when DHEC became involved in the regulation of waste tires, Proctor timely applied for all required permits.Â  Proctor became a permitted facility for both waste tire processing and waste tire disposal.Â  
The business of waste tire disposal turns on the availability of a per-tire rebate allowed by the South Carolina Department of Revenue.Â  Section 44-96-170(N) requires sellers of new tires to pay a two-dollar fee to the Department of Transportation for every new tire sold.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-96-170(N) (2005).Â  However, section 44-96-170(O) provides, â€œA wholesaler or retailer required to submit a fee pursuant to subsection (N) who delivers or arranges delivery of waste tires to a permitted or approved waste tire recycling facility . . . may apply for a refund of one dollar for each tire delivered.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-96-170(O) (2005).Â  A tire retailer is entitled to a one-dollar rebate per tire for each used tire delivered to a permitted waste tire facility.Â  Hence, the rebate essentially pays for the new-tire dealerâ€™s disposal of waste tires as the dealer pays a dollar to a waste tire disposal facility and gets back a dollar via the rebate.
DHEC maintains a list of approved waste tire recycling facilities.Â  DHEC forwards the list to the Department of Revenue, and the Department of Revenue provides the rebate.Â Â  The Director of Solid Waste Management, and later the Director of Solid Waste Reduction and Recycling with the Bureau of Land and Waste Management, William Culler, compiled the rebate list.Â  
In 1998, DHEC found Proctor in violation of his permit and DHEC regulations.Â  DHEC initiated an enforcement action, levied a fine against Proctor, and removed him from the rebate list.Â  The case was eventually heard by this Court and resulted in an unpublished opinion.Â  The underlying facts of the instant action are described in our prior opinion:Â  

DHEC deferred enforcement action based on Proctorâ€™s commitment to build sheds where used tires for sale to the public could be separately stored.Â  However, only one shed was constructed, and site conditions did not improve.Â  
In September 1998, DHEC issued an administrative order to Proctor to take corrective action at the site and pay a civil penalty of $51,330.Â  The order cited Proctor for numerous violations relating to storage of waste tires and removed Proctor from DHECâ€™s Waste Tire Facility Rebate List. . . .

App. 2000) (â€œThe dictates of Rule 401 are subject to the balancing requirement of Rule 403, SCRE, which requires a court to exclude relevant evidence upon a showing that its admission would be more prejudicial than probative.â€).Â  
The evidence at issue here was necessary as a means of introducing the jury to the background events leading up to the period of time from 2000 through the date of the trial.Â  For example, an e-mail referenced by Proctor served to show that DHEC officials were in a position to interact directly with retail sellers and would have knowledge of the rebate listâ€™s impact on a facilityâ€™s business.Â  Moreover, the facts surrounding this e-mail and any other acts prior to 2000 were excluded from consideration by the jury for damages.Â  The trial court specifically charged that â€œ[t]he period here for which you are concerned with is that period commencing with July the 27th, 2000.â€Â  The information relating to what happened prior to the issues in this case was relevant to the questions to be decided at trial.Â  Furthermore, the trial court properly charged the jury that they should consider only those acts occurring after July 27th, 2000.Â  Accordingly, we find no error.Â  
IV.Â  Lost Profits/Damages
DHEC asserts three issues dealing with lost profits and damages: (1) that the court erred in denying DHECâ€™s directed verdict motion as to damages and in charging the jury as to lost profits; (2) that the court erred in refusing DHECâ€™s request for a jury instruction limiting Proctorâ€™s damages to $9,500; and (3) that the damages were so excessive as to require a new trial absolute, or a new trial nisi remittitur.Â  
A.Â  Reasonable Certainty Standard
DHEC did not request the trial court to submit a special verdict form to determine whether the actual damages were for lost profits, loss of goodwill, or some other measure.Â  Without a special verdict form, it would be speculative for this Court to determine what portion of the award the jury attributed to lost profits as opposed to other tort damages.Â  See Moore v. Moore, 360 S.C. 241, 251, 599 S.E.2d 467, 472 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Even so, the law does not require absolute certainty of data upon which lost profits
are to be determined, but requires such reasonable certainty that damages are not based upon speculation and conjecture.Â  It is sufficient if there is a certain standard or fixed method by which profits may be estimated and determined with a fair degree of accuracy.Â  Beck v. Clarkson, 300 S.C. 293, 298-99, 387 S.E.2d 681, 684 (Ct. App. 1989) (quoting South Carolina Fin. Corp. of Anderson v. West Side Fin. Co., 236 S.C. 109, 113 S.E.2d 329 (1960)).
â€œâ€˜Profitsâ€™ have been defined as the â€˜net pecuniary gain from a transaction, the gross pecuniary gains diminished by the cost of obtaining them.â€™â€Â  Moore, 360 S.C. at 253, 599 S.E.2d at 473 (quoting Restatement of Contracts Â§ 331, Comment B (1932)); see also Mali v. Odom, 295 S.C. 78, 367 S.E.2d 166 (Ct. App. 1988) (defining profits as the net of income over expenditures during a given period).Â  
Drews Co., Inc. v. Ledwith-Wolfe Assocs., Inc., 296 S.C. 207, 371 S.E.2d 532 (1988), offers an erudite and comprehensive analysis of the standards governing recovery of lost profits:

The crucial requirement in lost profits determinations is that they be â€œestablished with reasonable certainty, for recovery cannot be had for profits that are conjectural or speculative.â€Â  South Carolina Finance Corp., supra, at 122, 113 S.E.2d at 336.Â  â€œThe proof must pass the realm of conjecture, speculation, or opinion not founded on facts, and must consist of actual facts from which a reasonably accurate conclusion regarding the cause and the amount of the loss can be logically and rationally drawn.â€Â  22 Am.Jur.2d Damages Â§ 641 (1988).

 Numerous proof techniques have been discussed and accepted in different factual scenarios.Â  See, e.g., Upjohn v. Rachelle Laboratories, Inc., 661 F.2d 1105, 1114 (6th Cir. 1981) (proof of future lost profits based on marketing forecasts by employees specializing in economic forecasting); Petty v. Weyerhaeuser Co., supra (skating rinkâ€™s projected revenues compared to those of another arena in a nearby town); see also Restatement (Second) of Contracts Â§ 352, at 146 (1981) (proof of lost profits â€œmay be established with reasonable certainty with the aid of expert testimony, economic and financial data, market surveys and analyses, business records of similar enterprises, and the like.â€); Note, supra, 48 Ohio St. L.J. at 872-3 (means of proving prospective profits include (1) â€œyardstickâ€ method of comparison with profit performance of business similar in size, nature, and location; (2) comparison with profit history of plaintiffâ€™s successor, where applicable; (3) comparison of similar businesses owned by plaintiff himself, and (4) use of economic and financial data and expert testimony).Â 

Drews Co., 296 S.C. at 213-14, 371 S.E.2d at 535-36.Â  The Drews Co. case dealt specifically with lost profits in the context of a new business.Â  The court explained: â€œWhile the factual contexts in which new business/lost profits cases arise will undoubtedly vary, these methods of proof and the â€˜reasonable certaintyâ€™ requirement bear an inherent flexibility facilitating the just assessment of profits lost to a new business due to contractual breach.â€Â  Id. at 214, 371 S.E.2d at 536.Â  Although the instant case does not involve lost profits of a new business, the courtâ€™s comment that the reasonable certainty requirement bears an inherent flexibility facilitating the just assessment of lost profits holds true here as well.
In Whisenant v. James Island Corp., 277 S.C. 10, 13, 281 S.E.2d 794, 796 (1981), our supreme court observed:

Generally, in order for damages to be recoverable, the evidence should be such as to enable the court or jury to determine the amount thereof with reasonable certainty or accuracy.Â  While neither the existence, causation nor amount of damages can be left to conjecture, guess or speculation, proof with mathematical certainty of the amount of loss or damage is not required.Â  Piggy Park Enterprises, Inc. v. Schofield, 251 S.C. 385, 162 S.E.2d 705 (1968); Gray v. Southern Facilities, Inc., 256 S.C. 558, 183 S.E.2d 438 (1971).

Accord Armstrong v. Collins, 366 S.C. 204, 621 S.E.2d 368 (Ct. App. 2005); Collins Entmâ€™t, Inc. v. White, 363 S.C. 546, 611 S.E.2d 262 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Sterling Dev. Co. v. Collins, 309 S.C. 237, 242, 421 S.E.2d 402, 405 (1992) (â€œIn claiming lost profits, the degree of proof required is that of reasonable certainty. . . .Â  The proof must pass the realm of conjecture, speculation or opinion not founded on facts, and must consist of actual facts from which a reasonably accurate conclusion regarding the cause and the amount of the loss can be logically and rationally drawn.â€) (citations omitted).Â  In Piggy Park Enterprises, Inc. v. Schofield, 251 S.C. 385, 162 S.E.2d 705 (1968), the supreme court inculcated:

It is, of course, true that the existence or amount of damages cannot be left to conjecture, guess or speculation. 
â€˜As a general rule, the evidence should be such as to enable the court or jury to determine * * * the amount of damages with reasonable certainty or accuracy; and it is sufficient if they are so established. 

â€˜Proof of the amount of loss with absolute or mathematical certainty is not required, and it does not matter that the determination of damages depends to some extent on the consideration of contingent events.Â  So, it had been held sufficient if a reasonable basis of computation is afforded, even though the result may be only approximate, or to adduce evidence which is the best the case is susceptible of under the circumstances and which will permit a reasonably close estimate of the loss.â€™ 25A C.J.S. Damages Â§ 162(2), p. 80. Cf. Powers v. Calvert Fire Ins. Co., 216 S.C. 309, 57 S.E.2d 638, 16 A.L.R.2d 1261; S. C. Electric & Gas Co. v. Aetna Ins. Co., 233 S.C. 557, 106 S.E.2d 276.

Piggy Park Enterprises, 251 S.C. at 391-92, 162 S.E.2d at 708.Â  â€œThe problematic nature of proving damages for loss of profits in a tort action will not prevent recovery where . . . the plaintiff can present evidence from which the court can make â€˜fair and reasonable approximation of them.â€™â€Â  Petty v. Weyerhaeuser Co., 288 S.C. 349, 355-56, 342 S.E.2d 611, 615-16 (Ct. App. 1986) (citations omitted).
1.Â  Directed Verdict
DHEC contends the trial court should have directed a verdict in its favor for failure to prove damages.Â  At the close of trial, DHEC moved for a directed verdict on damages, arguing: 

And also the third ground for my motion for directed verdict is the failure to prove his damages in this case by evidence that the jury can look at and not engage in speculation or conjecture, and thereâ€™s been no proper proof of damages in this case.

In its brief, DHEC reiterates, â€œProctor failed to introduce any evidence that a jury could use to determine an amount of damages.â€Â  We disagree.Â  
In this case, the evidence advanced at trial supports the juryâ€™s award of damages. Â The evidence showed there are three million tires discarded in South Carolina each year and there are fewer than ten waste tire facilities in the State.Â  Because Proctor was not on the rebate list, he was unable to sustain contracts with his major customers and lost the dollar he would have received for every tire he took into the facility.Â  Proctorâ€™s customers disposed of over 15,000 tires per quarter, each of which was subject to the one-dollar rebate.Â  Moreover, Proctor testified that â€œthirty-three to forty percent of the tires we got [from Samâ€™s Club] we could sell them and make a profit[.]â€Â  Thus, from 2000 until the time Proctor was returned to the list, he lost the rebate for each tire he would have received from Samâ€™s Club, plus lost profits from thirty-three to forty percent of the tires he would have sold as used tires.Â  Further, Proctor sold chips from tires for playgrounds, carpet backing, and septic systems.Â Â Â  
Proctor demonstrated that between 2000 and 2001, his company paid approximately $9,500 to take tires to another processing facility after he was removed from the rebate list.Â  Proctor presented evidence of the number of tires his business processed per year from 1995 through 2004, which included 30,000 tires in 1995, and 60,000 tires in 1996.Â  Proctor asseverated that as a result of DHECâ€™s actions, Anderson Tire Recyclingâ€™s business reputation had been damaged and had not yet recovered.Â  
We find sufficient evidence of damages to support the trial judgeâ€™s submitting this case to the jury.Â  See S.C. Prop. & Guar. Assâ€™n v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 521, 548 S.E.2d 880, 884-85 (Ct. App. 2001) (noting on appeal from the denial of a motion for a directed verdict, the appellate court may only reverse if there is no evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s ruling).
2.Â  Jury Instructions
Similarly, we reject DHECâ€™s argument that the court erred by not charging the jury that Proctorâ€™s damages, if any, were limited to $9,500.Â  â€œWhen instructing the jury, the trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.â€Â  Cohens v. Atkins, 333 S.C. 345, 349, 509 S.E.2d 286, 289 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  In reviewing a jury charge for alleged error, the appellate court must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues presented at trial.Â  Daves v. Cleary, 355 S.C. 216, 224, 584 S.E.2d 423, 427 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If the charge is reasonably free from error, isolated portions which might be misleading do not constitute reversible error.Â  Id.Â  â€œTo warrant reversal for refusal to give a requested instruction, the refusal must have not only been erroneous, but prejudicial as well.â€Â  Cohens, 333 S.C. at 349, 509 S.E.2d at 289.Â  Proctor proffered evidence of damages beyond the $9,500 he paid to another facility to take tires.Â  Therefore, the trial judge did not err by rejecting DHECâ€™s request to charge.Â  
B.Â  Excessive Damagesâ€”New Trial Absolute/New Trial Nisi Remittitur
Finally, DHEC contends the amount of damages found by the jury was so unduly liberal or grossly excessive as to require a new trial nisi remittitur or a new trial absolute.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œA new trial nisi is one in which a new trial will be granted unless the party opposing it complies with a condition set by the court.â€Â  Waring v. Johnson, 341 S.C. 248, 257, 533 S.E.2d 906, 911 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing Elliot v. Black River Elec. Coop., 233 S.C. 233, 104 S.E.2d 357 (1958)).Â  The grant or denial of new trial motions rests within the discretion of the trial judge, and his decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless his findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by error of law.Â  Chapman v. Upstate RV & Marine, 364 S.C. 82, 88-89, 610 S.E.2d 852, 856 (Ct. App. 2005); Waring, 341 S.C. at 256, 533 S.E.2d at 910; Vinson v. Hartley, 324 S.C. 389, 405, 477 S.E.2d 715, 723 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The trial court alone has the power to grant a new trial nisi when he finds the amount of the verdict to be merely inadequate or excessive.Â  Chapman, 364 S.C. at 89, 610 S.E.2d at 856 (citing McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 457 S.E.2d 603 (1995)); see also Evans v. Taylor Made Sandwich Co., 337 S.C. 95, 99, 522 S.E.2d 350, 352 (Ct. App. 1999) (noting that when the juryâ€™s verdict is inadequate or excessive, the trial judge has the discretionary power to grant a new trial nisi); Hawkins v. Greenwood Development Corp., 328 S.C. 585, 493 S.E.2d 875 (Ct. App. 1997) (same).Â  However, compelling reasons must be given to justify invading the juryâ€™s province by granting a new trial nisi remittitur.Â  Cf. Pelican Bldg. Ctrs. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 61, 427 S.E.2d 673, 676 (1993).Â  The consideration for a motion for a new trial nisi remittitur requires the trial judge to consider the adequacy of the verdict in light of the evidence presented.Â  Cf. Vinson, 324 S.C. at 405, 477 S.E.2d at 723.Â  Great deference is given to the trial judge â€œwho heard the evidence and is more familiar with the evidentiary atmosphere at trial,â€ and who thus â€œpossesses a better-informed view of the damages than this Court.â€Â 
Id. at 405-06, 477 S.E.2d at 723 (citing Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 426 S.E.2d 802 (1993)); accord Waring, 341 S.C. at 257, 533 S.E.2d at 911.Â  
â€œWhen considering a motion for a new trial based on the inadequacy or excessiveness of the juryâ€™s verdict, the trial court must distinguish between awards that are merely unduly liberal or conservative and awards that are actuated by passion, caprice, or prejudice.â€Â  Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 27, 602 S.E.2d 772, 781 (2004); accord Evans, 337 S.C. at 99-100, 522 S.E.2d at 352.Â  â€œIf the amount of the verdict is grossly inadequate or excessive so as to be the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, or some other influence outside the evidence, the trial judge must grant a new trial absolute.â€Â  Harrison v. Bevilacqua, 354 S.C. 129, 140, 580 S.E.2d 109, 115 (2003) (internal quotation marks omitted) (quoting Oâ€™Neal v. Bowles, 314 S.C. 525, 527, 431 S.E.2d 555, 556 (1993)).Â  
â€œThe decision to grant or deny a new trial absolute based on the excessiveness of a verdict rests in the sound discretion of the trial court and will not ordinarily be disturbed on appeal.â€Â  Elam, 361 S.C. at 27, 602 S.E.2d at 781; see Crawford v. Charleston-Isle of Palms Traction Co., 126 S.C. 447, 120 S.E. 381 (1923) (observing the refusal to grant a new trial on the ground that the verdict was excessive was addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge).Â  â€œIn deciding whether to assess error when a new trial motion is denied, the appellate court must consider the testimony and reasonable inferences therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€Â  Becker v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 339 S.C. 629, 635-36, 529 S.E.2d 758, 761-62 (Ct. App. 2000) (footnote omitted).Â  â€œThe juryâ€™s determination of damages, however, is entitled to substantial deference.â€Â  Harrison, 354 S.C. at 140, 580 S.E.2d at 115.
As stated by the Vinson court:

A trial court may grant a new trial absolute on the ground that the verdict is excessive or inadequate.Â  Rush v. Blanchard, 310 S.C. 375, 426 S.E.2d 802 (1993).Â  The juryâ€™s determination of damages, however, is entitled to substantial deference.Â  Id.Â  The trial judge must grant a new trial absolute if the amount of the verdict is grossly inadequate or excessive so as to shock the conscience of the court and clearly indicates the figure reached was the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, partiality, corruption or some other improper motives.Â  See Cock-n-Bull Steak House, Inc. v. Generali Ins. Co., ___ S.C. ___, 466 S.E.2d 727 (1996); McCourt by and Through McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 457 S.E.2d 603 (1995); Allstate Ins. Co. v. Durham, 314 S.C. 529, 431 S.E.2d 557 (1993); Oâ€™Neal v. Bowles, 314 S.C. 525, 431 S.E.2d 555 (1993); Rush, supra.Â  The failure of the trial judge to grant a new trial absolute in this situation amounts to an abuse of discretion and on appeal this Court will grant a new trial absolute.Â  Weir v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs., Inc., 312 S.C. 511, 435 S.E.2d 864 (1993); Allstate, supra; Oâ€™Neal, supra.


 The grant or denial of new trial motions rests within the discretion of the trial judge and his decision will not be disturbed on appeal unless his findings are wholly unsupported by the evidence or the conclusions reached are controlled by error of law.Â  Umhoefer v. Bollinger, 298 S.C. 221, 379 S.E.2d 296 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  See also Boozer v. Boozer, 300 S.C. 282, 387 S.E.2d 674 (Ct. App. 1988) (Court of Appeals has no power to review trial courtâ€™s ruling unless it rests on basis of fact wholly unsupported by evidence or is controlled by error of law).Â  In deciding whether to assess error to a courtâ€™s denial of a motion for a new trial, we must consider the testimony and reasonable inferences to be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Umhoefer, supra.
Vinson, 324 S.C. at 404-05, 477 S.E.2d at 723; see also Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 302, 536 S.E.2d 408, 420 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œ[T]o warrant a new trial absolute, the verdict reached must be so â€˜grossly excessiveâ€™ as to clearly indicate the influence of an improper motive on the jury.â€).Â  If the verdict is grossly inadequate or excessive, such that it is the result of passion, caprice, prejudice, or some other influence outside the evidence, the trial court must grant a new trial absolute.Â  Oâ€™Neal v. Bowles, 314 S.C. 525, 527, 431 S.E.2d 55, 56 (1993); Waring v. Johnson, 341 S.C. 248, 257, 533 S.E.2d 906, 911 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
The decision to grant a new trial nisi remittitur is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  This record contains sufficient evidence to support his ruling.Â  Because the evidence supports the juryâ€™s verdict, we disagree that the damages are grossly excessive so as to suggest the jury was motivated by passion, caprice, or prejudice.Â  The trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying DHECâ€™s motions for a new trial nisi remittitur and a new trial absolute.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based upon the foregoing, the trial courtâ€™s order is
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE, J., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Willie James, Petitioner
v.
State of South Carolina, Respondent
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4099
Submitted January 30, 2006 â€“ Filed March 27, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, Office of Appellate Defense, Â of Columbia, for Petitioner.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott and Assistant Attorney General Sabrina Todd, Office of Attorney General, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.: Â This is a PCR case.Â  The petitioner Willie James contends his counsel was ineffective for not objecting to the Stateâ€™s failure to provide written notice to him of its intention to seek a sentence of life imprisonment without parole as required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(H) (2003). Â The trial court dismissed Jamesâ€™ petition.Â  We reverse and remand for resentencing.
An indictment charged James with armed robbery.Â  Because he had a prior armed robbery conviction, the State sought to have him sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-25-45(A)(1) (2003).Â  South Carolina Code section 17-25-45(H) provides the following regarding notice: 

Where the solicitor is required to seek or determines to seek sentencing of a defendant under this section, written notice must be given by the solicitor to the defendant and defendantâ€™s counsel not less than ten days before trial.[1]Â  

The trial court found defense counsel received the required written notice but James did not; however, the trial court also found James had actual notice of the Stateâ€™s intention to seek a sentence of life imprisonment without parole.
Our recent case of State v. Johnson[2] controls the result here.Â  In Johnson, a majority of this court held insufficient the notice required by section 17-25-45(H) where the State served written notice upon the defendant but not upon his counsel, notwithstanding both the defendant and his lawyer had actual notice of the Stateâ€™s intention to seek a sentence of life imprisonment without parole.Â  The court observed:

By its words in the recidivist statute, the General Assembly has mandated that the solicitor â€œmustâ€ notify the defendant and the defendantâ€™s counsel in writing if the solicitor intends to seek a life sentence without the possibility of parole.Â  For this Court to dismiss the clear and unambiguous language of the statute and merely require the defendantâ€™s counsel to have actual notice of the solicitorâ€™s intent to seek life without parole would have the effect of amending the statute.Â  In our view, actual notice under section 17-25-45(H) is insufficient unless and until the General Assembly decides otherwise and amends the statute itself.[3]

As noted in footnote two, supra, the supreme court declined to review the decision. Â It did so, notwithstanding one judge dissented.[4]Â  
We discern no meaningful distinction between the Johnson case and the one here. Â The statute in question requires both a defendant and defendantâ€™s counsel to receive written notice of the Stateâ€™s intention.Â  In Johnson, the solicitor notified the defendant in writing but not the defendantâ€™s counsel; here, the solicitor notified the defendantâ€™s counsel in writing but not the defendant.Â  To paraphrase the majorityâ€™s words in Johnson, for this court to dismiss the clear and unambiguous language of the statute and merely require the defendant to have actual notice of the solicitorâ€™s intent to seek life imprisonment without parole would have the effect of amending the statute.Â  The statute is the same today as it was when this court decided Johnson. 
Regarding the Stateâ€™s argument that written notice to defense counsel sufficed to provide written notice to the defendant because defense counsel served as the defendantâ€™s agent, we can only say not in this case â€“ not where the statute, as this court held in Johnson, in clear and unambiguous language requires both a defendant and his counsel to be served with written notice.Â  If a defendantâ€™s actual notice is insufficient to satisfy the requirements of section 17-25-45(H), then his imputed knowledge certainly is.
To establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, a PCR applicant must prove trial counselâ€™s representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness and there is a reasonable probability the result would have been different but for counselâ€™s error.[5]Â  James made such a showing here when he proved counsel did not raise the issue of the Stateâ€™s failure to serve the defendant with written notice, even though the statute, as this court later held, plainly required a defendant to be so served, and as a result James was sentenced to life imprisonment without the possibility of parole in violation of the statute.Â  This failure obviously prejudiced him.Â  Moreover, that this court decided Johnson after the trial court sentenced James is of little moment in view of the â€œclear and unambiguous languageâ€[6] of section 17-25-45(H).
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â Â Â

[3] Â 347 S.C. at 70, 552 S.E.2d at 340.
[4] Â See Rule 226(b)(2), SCACR (listing a dissent in the decision of the Court of Appeals as a factor in determining whether to grant certiorari).
[5]Â  Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 104 S.Ct. 2052, 80 L.Ed.2d 674 (1984).
